description: Mac Management Basics is the first step in the Apple IT Pro certification path. Viewers who complete this exam will be awarded the Apple Certified Associate certification. The exam covers topics related to managing Macintosh networks and focuses on topics like deploying OS X, deploying software application, controlling machines with polices, and keeping systems up to date. It is an excellent starting point for anyone tasked with managing multiple Macintosh PCs.
name: ACA Mac Management Basics 10.11
subtitle: Apple Certificed Associate

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce the image types that can be used to provision OS X El Capitan to machines. They explore system images like NetBoot, NetInstall, NetRestore and disk images like "dmg" files and the scenarios in which an administrator might use the different images as well as the utilities used to work with these image file types.
episodes.title: Installation Images

1

00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:10.640

23
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:17.190

00:01:17.190 --> 00:01:20.310

00:01:21.990 --> 00:01:24.710

27

You might need to do this not just once or
twice, but hundreds or

28
00:01:27.680 --> 00:01:29.660
even thousands of times, right.

29
00:01:29.660 --> 00:01:31.410
Let me give you a scenario here.

30
00:01:31.410 --> 00:01:32.880
Let's say that you work for

31

00:01:36.100 --> 00:01:38.970

we've finally got some budget money in and

33
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:41.330
we are going to refresh all
the computers in the school.

34
00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:45.810
So, we're going to buy 1,000 computers and
we need to get them deployed.

35
00:01:45.810 --> 00:01:48.460
They needed to be running
the latest version of OSX, so

36
00:01:48.460 --> 00:01:51.200
we need to be running El Capitan, right.

37
00:01:51.200 --> 00:01:54.490
And, we need to have our educational
software loaded on them.

38
00:01:54.490 --> 00:01:55.780
Well, I got a choice.

39
00:01:55.780 --> 00:01:59.930
I could, one by one,

40
00:01:59.930 --> 00:02:03.400

41
00:02:03.400 --> 00:02:07.510
I could then install the school

42
00:02:07.510 --> 00:02:10.970
And I could do it 1000 times,

43
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:14.460
Now, if you're an hourly
employee that's cool, right.

44
00:02:14.460 --> 00:02:15.560
Hey, it's job security.

45
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:18.570

hours for months on end.

46
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:21.250

done by the end of the week, and

47
00:02:21.250 --> 00:02:23.510
you've got a very small IT department.

48
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:27.030
Which most companies do,
you need a way to get it done faster.

49
00:02:27.030 --> 00:02:29.720
And so, what we can do is,
we can build installation images.

50
00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:34.040
That have OSX setup,
exactly the way that we wanted.

51
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:38.120
That has the user accounts that we need,
that has the software that we want in

52
00:02:38.120 --> 00:02:41.862
there, that has everything
already baked in.

53
00:02:41.862 --> 00:02:44.060
So that,
when I get those thousand machines,

54
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:47.620
all I have to do is power them on and
start the installation process.

55
00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:51.310
It'll install OS10 and have it completely
set up the way that we wanted.

56
00:02:51.310 --> 00:02:54.312
And now, you can rapidly provision
large quantities of machines.

57
00:02:54.312 --> 00:02:56.910
Now, you see why I say most
people don't care about this.

58
00:02:56.910 --> 00:02:59.690
Is your home user gonna do this?

59
00:02:59.690 --> 00:03:00.350
No.

60
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:03.890
If you have five computers to set up or
even ten computers to set up.

61
00:03:03.890 --> 00:03:06.600
It's typically faster just
doing them by hand, right.

62
00:03:06.600 --> 00:03:09.290
Apple calls that a hands-off deployment.

63

And I think it's funny,
because it's not hands-off.

64
00:03:11.520 --> 00:03:13.720
You actually have to do a lot
of work to get them done.

65
00:03:13.720 --> 00:03:16.721
But it's technically your hands off,
right.

66
00:03:16.721 --> 00:03:19.996
[LAUGH] You could give them, I could
give Wes here a new laptop and say,

67
00:03:19.996 --> 00:03:21.334
here you go Wes, set it up.

68
00:03:21.334 --> 00:03:26.040
[LAUGH] And he can run through that
wizard and create his account.

69
00:03:26.040 --> 00:03:30.420
And start installing his software and
do it all himself, my hands are off.

70
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:36.490
But if I want a true hands off, they call
it a ZTI, a Zero Touch Installation.

71
00:03:36.490 --> 00:03:39.920
Where you bring up the Mac and
it just gets installed,

72
00:03:39.920 --> 00:03:41.620
has everything set up the way you want it.

73
00:03:41.620 --> 00:03:43.310
Well for that,

And let's call this one ibooks-v1.3,
all right?

521
00:24:56.075 --> 00:25:01.420
So, this will be another file,
except this time,

522
00:25:01.420 --> 00:25:06.190
instead of doing the standard read write
disk image, I'm gonna change that.

523
00:25:06.190 --> 00:25:09.270
And you'll see we've got
a few other options in here,

524
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:12.630
including the sparse disk image
that I mentioned earlier.

525
00:25:12.630 --> 00:25:18.440
A sparse disk image is just like the DMG,
except it leaves out the empty stuff.

526
00:25:18.440 --> 00:25:20.390
Why make a file that contains empty stuff?

527
00:25:20.390 --> 00:25:22.600
We can just leave that stuff out, okay?

528
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:25.930
So, I'm gonna go ahead and
do that, and I'll hit Save.

529
00:25:25.930 --> 00:25:29.370
And so, now,
I've created two of these files.

530
00:25:29.370 --> 00:25:32.420
And if I look on my desktop,
where did those thing end up?

531
00:25:32.420 --> 00:25:34.480
They're way over here.

532
00:25:34.480 --> 00:25:35.410
There we go.

533
00:25:35.410 --> 00:25:37.320
I can see I created these two files.

534
00:25:37.320 --> 00:25:39.330
And I guess my head's kind
of sitting on top of those.

535
00:25:40.380 --> 00:25:41.850
But I can see those two files.

536
00:25:41.850 --> 00:25:47.460
I've got iBooks version 1.2 dot dmg, and
iBooks version 1.3 dot sparse image.

537
00:25:47.460 --> 00:25:48.720
Right?
So, it's actually calling out

538
00:25:48.720 --> 00:25:53.060
the fact that it is a sparse image and
not a traditional DMG.

539
00:25:53.060 --> 00:25:56.790
It's a little bit different, and I can
double click on those guys to mount them.

540
00:25:56.790 --> 00:25:58.380
So, that's what I'm gonna do.

541
00:25:58.380 --> 00:26:00.310
So, I'll mount the first one.

542
00:26:00.310 --> 00:26:04.020
And then, I'll mount the second one, which
apparently it's gonna take it's time for,

543
00:26:04.020 --> 00:26:05.970
I'm guessing cuz I still
have that window open.

544
00:26:05.970 --> 00:26:06.660
There we go.

545
00:26:06.660 --> 00:26:10.230
And so, now I've got those two
guys mounted right here, right?

546
00:26:10.230 --> 00:26:12.300
And see how it's that friendly
name that I typed in?

547
00:26:12.300 --> 00:26:13.420
That's why we have two names.

548
00:26:13.420 --> 00:26:17.500
The file name, and then the friendly
name so that I can see those.

549
00:26:17.500 --> 00:26:20.430
And what I'm gonna do now is
I'm gonna take iBooks, and

550
00:26:20.430 --> 00:26:22.570
if I look at iBooks, how big is it?

551
00:26:22.570 --> 00:26:25.700
It's 51 MB in size, right?

552
00:26:25.700 --> 00:26:30.220
So, 62.9 MB on disk, but
51 MB in size of the actual file.

553
00:26:30.220 --> 00:26:34.920
And I'm gonna send a copy
of it to my version 1.2.

554
00:26:34.920 --> 00:26:37.010
And I'll send a copy of it to version 1.3.

555
00:26:37.010 --> 00:26:39.190
So, I'm just gonna copy it to those guys.

556
00:26:39.190 --> 00:26:40.360
All right.

557
00:26:40.360 --> 00:26:46.668
And if I browse into them, here's iBooks
v1.2, and I can see iBooks is right there.

558
00:26:46.668 --> 00:26:50.110
And iBooks v1.3,
I can see it's got the file, too, right?

559
00:26:50.110 --> 00:26:52.330
So, both discs now contain that.

560
00:26:52.330 --> 00:26:54.520
And if I go back up to my desktop and

561
00:26:54.520 --> 00:26:59.710
I look at the details of these files,
what I can see is the size.

562
00:26:59.710 --> 00:27:06.240
And if you look, iBooks version
1.2 is exactly 100 megabytes.

563
00:27:06.240 --> 00:27:11.830
A DMG will be a fixed size,
even the empty space, by default.

564
00:27:11.830 --> 00:27:13.363
But the sparse image?

565
00:27:13.363 --> 00:27:15.827
37.8, right?

566
00:27:15.827 --> 00:27:22.390
Not only did it make an image of the file,
it compressed it, too.

567
00:27:22.390 --> 00:27:25.572
And it left out the empty space and
ends up being pretty small, okay?

568
00:27:25.572 --> 00:27:27.950
And at the end of the day,
the sparseimage is a dmg.

569
00:27:27.950 --> 00:27:30.781
I can rename it to a dot dmg,
and it'll work just fine.

570
00:27:30.781 --> 00:27:33.198
And that's what you'd normally
do before you distribute it, and

571
00:27:33.198 --> 00:27:34.548
nobody distributes a sparseimage.

572
00:27:34.548 --> 00:27:36.120
They distribute a dmg, right?

573
00:27:36.120 --> 00:27:38.090
So, you can just rename that,
and then you're in business.

574
00:27:38.090 --> 00:27:39.770
They'll work the same
once they're created.

575
00:27:39.770 --> 00:27:40.480
But that is important.

576
00:27:40.480 --> 00:27:45.740
So, on the exam, you'll see that
difference between a sparse disk image and

577
00:27:45.740 --> 00:27:47.810
a regular read write disk image.

578
00:27:47.810 --> 00:27:52.012
Regular read write has a fixed size
whether you put data in it or not.

579
00:27:52.012 --> 00:27:52.800
All right.

580
00:27:52.800 --> 00:27:56.550
Once you've got these created, they can
be distributed however you want, right?

581
00:27:56.550 --> 00:28:00.060
So, if I go down here, I need to eject
them before I mess around with them.

582
00:28:00.060 --> 00:28:02.580
So, I'm just gonna eject
those two virtual disks.

583
00:28:02.580 --> 00:28:04.860
And we'll give that a second
while it gets rid of them.

584
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:07.489
And then, once they're gone, like I said,

585
00:28:07.489 --> 00:28:10.492
I can rename that version
1.3 file eventually.

586
00:28:10.492 --> 00:28:13.430
Wow, apparently really likes those files.

587
00:28:13.430 --> 00:28:14.480
There we go.

588
00:28:14.480 --> 00:28:17.870
So, I can take that version 1.3 file and
I'm just gonna rename it.

589
00:28:17.870 --> 00:28:18.683
So, it's a dmg.

590
00:28:20.390 --> 00:28:22.230
And we'll do that.

591
00:28:22.230 --> 00:28:23.090
There we go.

592
00:28:23.090 --> 00:28:26.540
And now, I've effectively got two
files that I can distribute out and

593
00:28:26.540 --> 00:28:31.130
people can use and be happy with and
the world is a safer place, right?

594
00:28:31.130 --> 00:28:33.520
So, this is what you're getting when
you download software from vendors.

595
00:28:33.520 --> 00:28:35.950
They're distributing these DMG files.

596
00:28:35.950 --> 00:28:39.430
All right, now that is one of
the file types, the image types,

597
00:28:39.430 --> 00:28:40.940
that we're going to talk
about in this series.

598
00:28:40.940 --> 00:28:43.895
And it's probably the, I don't want
to say it's the least important,

599
00:28:43.895 --> 00:28:46.190
cuz there's exam questions and
that makes it important.

600
00:28:46.190 --> 00:28:49.260
But in real life land, it's the one
you're least likely to create, right?

601
00:28:49.260 --> 00:28:52.350
Because, normally, if you're a software
developer, then, yes, you'll create them.

602
00:28:52.350 --> 00:28:56.040
But otherwise, the rest of us are going
to create Net Install, Net Boot, or

603
00:28:56.040 --> 00:28:56.990
Net Restore images.

604
00:28:56.990 --> 00:29:00.040
And those are the ones that we're gonna
cover in the next couple of episodes.

605
00:29:00.040 --> 00:29:00.950
>> All right, Don.

606
00:29:00.950 --> 00:29:01.950
Great information.

607
00:29:01.950 --> 00:29:03.170
Lot of good stuff in there.

608
00:29:03.170 --> 00:29:06.240
We're going to just touch base
with the different image types.

609
00:29:06.240 --> 00:29:06.762
They're coming up.

610
00:29:06.762 --> 00:29:09.170
We're gonna get into them
a lot more coming up.

611
00:29:09.170 --> 00:29:11.540
Don, do you have anything else for
us in this episode?

612
00:29:11.540 --> 00:29:12.770
>> Those are the key things there.

613
00:29:12.770 --> 00:29:14.730
Just remember those images
we created are not bootable.

614
00:29:14.730 --> 00:29:16.180
I think I've probably
said it 20 times now.

615
00:29:16.180 --> 00:29:17.370
That's a key element to remember.

616
00:29:17.370 --> 00:29:19.640
And then, just remember the difference
between a sparse image and

617
00:29:19.640 --> 00:29:21.080
a traditional DMG.

618
00:29:21.080 --> 00:29:22.200
Just that size difference.

619
00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:23.630
So, the key components.

620
00:29:23.630 --> 00:29:24.130
>> Very good.

621
00:29:24.130 --> 00:29:27.170
Well, it looks like we've come to
the end of another exciting episode here

622
00:29:27.170 --> 00:29:28.080
at ITProTV.

623
00:29:28.080 --> 00:29:32.180
But stick around, cuz we got plenty of
more episodes to come with Mac, here.

624
00:29:32.180 --> 00:29:34.820
So s,igning off for
ITPRO.TV, I'm Wes Brian.

00:29:34.820 --> 00:29:35.530
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:29:35.530 --> 00:29:37.222

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don look at installation images. They talk about NetInstall and using the System Image utility. They will also dicuss how to customize setting using the Automater. They demonstrate the OS X utilities Disk Utility and System Image Utility.
episodes.title: Building NetInstall Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.748 --> 00:00:16.077
Hello, and welcome back to another
exciting episode here ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.077 --> 00:00:17.361
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:17.361 --> 00:00:20.020
In todays episode we're
gonna be continuing along

5
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:24.310
with our Mac management basics 10.11,
also known as El Capitan.

6
00:00:24.310 --> 00:00:27.650
And we've got Don Pezet here to
help us out with our episode today.

7
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:29.190
Don, how you doing and welcome?

8
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:30.460
>> I'm doing swell, Wes,

9
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:32.710
ready to jump right back in to
the world of Mac management basics.

10
00:00:32.710 --> 00:00:36.730
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at NetInstall, well,

11
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:39.080
and to a lesser extent, NetBoot also.

12
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:40.140
Building up NetInstall and

13
00:00:40.140 --> 00:00:44.310
NetBoot images to be able to deploy Mac OS
out to our production environments and

14
00:00:44.310 --> 00:00:48.600
get hundred, thousands, tens of thousands
of machines all set up simultaneously.

15
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:53.400
So you'll see the process actually not
that complex it goes pretty smooth and

16
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:56.811
it's a really valuable asset to have for
a corporate environment.

17
00:00:56.811 --> 00:01:00.380
All right, well lets kick things off let
me just do a quick recap of the difference

18
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:06.330
between net install and net boot right so
NetBoot images are operating

19
00:01:06.330 --> 00:01:10.050
system images that we build with Mac OS
that are available via the network.

20
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:15.090
And you can start up any Mac on your
network and it can find that NetBoot image

21
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:19.540
across the network, it can load
it locally, and boot up, and run.

22
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:20.750
All right?

23
00:01:20.750 --> 00:01:24.580
But the key piece here is with NetBoot
it doesn't install to the hard drive.

24
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:27.830
It caches files on the hard drive but
it doesn't actually install the OS.

25
00:01:27.830 --> 00:01:30.970
So if you power the computer off again,
that data's now gone.

26
00:01:30.970 --> 00:01:32.770
And when you fire the computer back up,

27
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:36.500
it's gotta reload the operating
system over the network again, right.

28
00:01:36.500 --> 00:01:40.300
NetBoot is just designed to, like
the name implies, boot off the network.

29
00:01:40.300 --> 00:01:41.720
Just to get us up and running.

30
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:45.480
It's great for troubleshooting, for
testing, or in environments where we

31
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:50.060
just don't want our machines to save
changes, things like a student lab

32
00:01:50.060 --> 00:01:53.290
where you might not want the students
to modify things and it stays around.

33
00:01:53.290 --> 00:01:56.620
Here you can just reboot the system and
it'll come up nice and clean every time.

34
00:01:56.620 --> 00:01:58.530
NetInstall is a little different.

35
00:01:58.530 --> 00:02:00.950
You boot up the computer,
it reaches out on the network,

36
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:05.330
it finds the NetInstall image and now
instead of just loading it via network,

37
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:09.200
it actually installs it to the hard
drive so that the next time you boot up

38
00:02:09.200 --> 00:02:11.510
you just boot up off of your hard
drive instead of the network.

39
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:16.890
It's a great way to get OS 10 installed or
even upgraded on your system.

40
00:02:16.890 --> 00:02:20.170
The example I gave in the last episode,
was you might have 1,000 computers that

41
00:02:20.170 --> 00:02:25.780
are out there that are all running OS
10.10, right, so you're running Mavericks.

42
00:02:25.780 --> 00:02:29.670
And you wanna upgrade, or
10.10 is Yosemite, well, whatever.

43
00:02:29.670 --> 00:02:32.200
We want to upgrade to El Capitan, right?

44
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:34.580
So when I wanna upgrade to El Capitan,

45
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:38.510
I could log in to the app store on all
1,000 machines and install it that way.

46
00:02:38.510 --> 00:02:40.030
But I don't wanna log
in on those machines.

47
00:02:40.030 --> 00:02:42.190
I don't want to share credentials or
whatever.

48
00:02:42.190 --> 00:02:45.690
So instead I could take
the El Capitan installer and

49
00:02:45.690 --> 00:02:48.080
serve it up as a NetInstall image.

50
00:02:48.080 --> 00:02:50.990
And now when systems boot up
they can install from that and

51
00:02:50.990 --> 00:02:52.550
they don't even have to
have an iTunes account.

52
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:55.040
We can push it out and
get it deployed in our systems.

53
00:02:55.040 --> 00:03:00.000
So NetInstall installs locally,
net boot run temporarily.

54
00:03:00.000 --> 00:03:01.660
That's the big difference between the two.

55
00:03:01.660 --> 00:03:04.680
>> Now with the imaged on itself,
is this a stock image?

56
00:03:04.680 --> 00:03:08.520
Is this something we can maybe leverage
some kind of customization if we need to

57
00:03:08.520 --> 00:03:11.650
peek and tweak it to suit our needs if
the stock install doesn't, you know,

58
00:03:11.650 --> 00:03:12.760
suit what we're doing?

59
00:03:12.760 --> 00:03:17.150
Yeah, so normally we do kinda what I
said a minute ago, which is we take the,

60
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:20.560
in this case the El Capitan installer and
we use that as our source image.

61
00:03:20.560 --> 00:03:23.410
So at a minimum,
you could just deploy that stock, right?

62
00:03:23.410 --> 00:03:27.540
It would be a, just like Apple
intended installation of El Capitan.

63
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:28.710
And that works out great,

64
00:03:28.710 --> 00:03:32.140
use the El Capitan installer as
your source, and you're done.

65
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:34.060
But usually we wanna do
a little more than that, right?

66
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:37.370
Maybe you wanna configure
Open Directory on the machines or

67
00:03:37.370 --> 00:03:41.540
you wanna have some kind of help desk
user account created or some other

68
00:03:41.540 --> 00:03:45.220
configuration change on the system may
be as simple as changing the wallpaper.

69
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:46.240
Well, you can do that.

70
00:03:46.240 --> 00:03:50.490
You can customized your NetInstall images
and your NetBoot images to contain

71
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:54.740
the changes that make it match your
environment, so it's really up to you.

72
00:03:54.740 --> 00:03:58.250
You can do stock, that's the easiest, or
you can tweak it and change it, and so

73
00:03:58.250 --> 00:03:59.550
that's what we're gonna
look at in this episode.

74
00:03:59.550 --> 00:04:04.480
We're gonna start with just kinda building
a stock image and getting that set up, and

75
00:04:04.480 --> 00:04:07.400
then we'll move on to creating one
that's customized that has a lot of

76
00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:10.450
additional bells and whistles or changes
or whatever it is that we want to modify.

77
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:14.620
>> Very good, and in the last episode
you did mention a tool that we can use,

78
00:04:14.620 --> 00:04:15.630
the Disk Utility.

79
00:04:15.630 --> 00:04:18.390
Now, Don, is that something that
we're gonna use, the Disk Utility,

80
00:04:18.390 --> 00:04:20.790
here when we Start
working with net install?

81
00:04:20.790 --> 00:04:21.940
>> No, it really isn't.

82
00:04:21.940 --> 00:04:25.270
I mean, it's a great tool, but one of the
things I mentioned in the last episode was

83
00:04:25.270 --> 00:04:26.780
that Disk Utility has some problems.

84
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:30.540
It doesn't make bootable images by
default, it just makes these DMGs.

85
00:04:30.540 --> 00:04:35.280
And it doesn't back up recovery
partitions, so we can't

86
00:04:35.280 --> 00:04:39.380
really build more than one partition
to the same DMG using Disk Utility.

87
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:40.470
For that,

88
00:04:40.470 --> 00:04:44.350
we have a different utility we're gonna
use called the System Image Utility.

89
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:47.330
Now the System Image Utility,
it's actually a part of Mac OS.

90
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:49.770
If you're on a Mac, you've already got it.

91
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:51.480
But it's kind of hidden away.

92
00:04:51.480 --> 00:04:52.690
It's not like our normal stuff.

93
00:04:52.690 --> 00:04:55.640
You know, normally,
if I want to find the Disk Utility,

94
00:04:55.640 --> 00:04:57.550
I would browse into my
applications folder.

95
00:04:57.550 --> 00:04:58.950
Let me do it here on my laptop.

96
00:04:58.950 --> 00:05:00.880
I would browse into
the applications folder.

97
00:05:00.880 --> 00:05:05.220
And in the applications folder I
would find the utilities folder,

98
00:05:05.220 --> 00:05:06.980
which is buried way down in here.

99
00:05:06.980 --> 00:05:09.320
And when I browse in the utilities folder,

100
00:05:09.320 --> 00:05:13.510
that's where I'm gonna see things like
Activity Monitor and Disk Utility, right,

101
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:15.330
that's what we were using
in the last episode.

102
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:17.010
So those utilities are right there.

103
00:05:17.010 --> 00:05:21.870
But if I look for the System Image
Utility, it's not here, right?

104
00:05:21.870 --> 00:05:27.190
This is one of those that's kind of buried
away deep in the dark confines of Mac OS.

105
00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:30.290
It's part of the operating system hidden
away inside of what's called the core

106
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:31.640
services, right?

107
00:05:31.640 --> 00:05:33.610
If you wanna find it the easiest way,

108
00:05:33.610 --> 00:05:35.430
honestly the easiest way
is to just use Spotlight.

109
00:05:35.430 --> 00:05:40.140
If I do a Spotlight search and I type
System Image Utility, It'll find it,

110
00:05:40.140 --> 00:05:43.710
and then I can run it, and there we go,
I'm in the System Image Utility, right?

111
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:46.190
But if you ever want to actually
find it on the hard drive,

112
00:05:46.190 --> 00:05:47.190
it's kind of buried away.

113
00:05:47.190 --> 00:05:48.460
Let me show you where it is.

114
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:53.340
I’m just going to use finders Go Menu and
I'll choose, Go to Folder.

115
00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:54.600
You can see, right?

116
00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:55.750
I've done it before.

117
00:05:55.750 --> 00:06:00.270
When you just go to folder you can

partitions on my system so

460
00:22:16.670 --> 00:22:18.370
I'm gonna leave that checked, all right.

461
00:22:18.370 --> 00:22:19.950
Then we'll just move forward on that,

462
00:22:19.950 --> 00:22:22.430
and it's gonna ask if I
wanna pick the hardware.

463
00:22:22.430 --> 00:22:26.860
Now, I've got a Mac Mini, and
I built the image on a Mac Mini.

464
00:22:26.860 --> 00:22:29.120
And so that might be all that
it's really suitable for.

465
00:22:29.120 --> 00:22:32.390
I might have power settings in
there that are not really good for

466
00:22:32.390 --> 00:22:35.480
a MacBook, for example.

467
00:22:35.480 --> 00:22:39.600
And so I might want to restrict
the hardware that I deploy it to.

468
00:22:39.600 --> 00:22:44.290
And you can even get really strict on
this, you can say particular Mac Minis.

469
00:22:44.290 --> 00:22:47.800
Like, hey, this one's got enough hardware
on it that it's not gonna work for

470
00:22:47.800 --> 00:22:48.870
the older Mac Minis.

471
00:22:48.870 --> 00:22:50.740
It's only gonna work on the newer ones.

472
00:22:50.740 --> 00:22:54.050
And so we can go through and
start to kinda cut this down and

473
00:22:54.050 --> 00:22:56.090
limit the amount of systems
that it'll be supported on.

474
00:22:56.090 --> 00:22:59.580
So you can really restrict that and
control it and kinda define that.

475
00:22:59.580 --> 00:23:01.600
I'm gonna leave mine open right now but

476
00:23:01.600 --> 00:23:03.680
in real life land you'll
usually wanna tweak that a bit.

477
00:23:05.600 --> 00:23:08.390
All right, after that I can filter
the MAC addresses that are allowed to

478
00:23:08.390 --> 00:23:11.340
even see this image, cuz I might not
want everybody to be able to see it.

479
00:23:11.340 --> 00:23:14.370
If this is a backup of my computer,

480
00:23:14.370 --> 00:23:17.040
I don't want everybody in
the network to see that backup.

481
00:23:17.040 --> 00:23:20.460
Cuz anybody who's bored could boot
up their computer to the network and

482
00:23:20.460 --> 00:23:22.310
say yeah, restore Don's image.

483
00:23:22.310 --> 00:23:23.760
And now they've got a copy of all my data.

484
00:23:23.760 --> 00:23:25.520
I don't want that, right?

485
00:23:25.520 --> 00:23:27.080
If it's just a lab machine,
what do I care, right?

486
00:23:27.080 --> 00:23:29.340
But if I'm doing backups of people's
machines I don't want that.

487
00:23:29.340 --> 00:23:32.300
So I might say hey,
I'm gonna back up Don's Mac.

488
00:23:32.300 --> 00:23:34.270
And when I do that, for

489
00:23:34.270 --> 00:23:39.320
that image, I'm only going to allow
this particular client to see it.

490
00:23:39.320 --> 00:23:42.367
So now they'd have to be at my
computer to restore my image.

491
00:23:42.367 --> 00:23:45.659
And if they're at my computer, I've got
bigger problems to worry about, right?

492
00:23:45.659 --> 00:23:48.172
So that one's ind of
already dealt with for me.

493
00:23:48.172 --> 00:23:51.745
Now, if I lose my computer and I have to
replace it, someone's gonna have to edit

494
00:23:51.745 --> 00:23:54.691
this image and come back and
add those additional MAC addresses for

495
00:23:54.691 --> 00:23:57.130
the new computer so
it'll be supported and detected.

496
00:23:57.130 --> 00:23:58.921
So that's one way that we can do it.

497
00:23:58.921 --> 00:24:01.004
This only applies for network installs.

498
00:24:01.004 --> 00:24:04.115
I'm gonna show you in another episode
how we can do USB installs too, and

499
00:24:04.115 --> 00:24:05.750
this doesn't apply to USB installs.

500
00:24:07.680 --> 00:24:10.290
All right, after that, it's got enough
information so I'm gonna go ahead and

501
00:24:10.290 --> 00:24:10.810
throw this.

502
00:24:10.810 --> 00:24:14.554
I'll put it on my external SSD so
I don't run out of hard drive space.

503
00:24:14.554 --> 00:24:19.365
And I'll throw it right over there
with our other images from yesterday,

504
00:24:19.365 --> 00:24:20.460
and there we go.

505
00:24:20.460 --> 00:24:22.610
It's going to start
building that net restore.

506
00:24:22.610 --> 00:24:25.220
It's gathering all the data
off that other machine.

507
00:24:25.220 --> 00:24:26.940
It's building that 15 gig image.

508
00:24:26.940 --> 00:24:31.670
It's putting in a recovery partition,
and it's going to compress it.

509
00:24:31.670 --> 00:24:34.580
So I don't expect this image to be 15 and
a half gigs.

510
00:24:34.580 --> 00:24:36.650
I think we saw with
the images we took yesterday,

511
00:24:36.650 --> 00:24:38.630
it ended up being more like 7 and
a half gigs.

512
00:24:38.630 --> 00:24:40.560
So I expect to see something like that.

513
00:24:40.560 --> 00:24:45.720
So it's gonna build up and
now I'm going to have a net restore image.

514
00:24:45.720 --> 00:24:48.790
>> We had a good question that
come in the chat room there, Don.

515
00:24:48.790 --> 00:24:51.240
In some other systems that we have,
we have to strip off things,

516
00:24:51.240 --> 00:24:53.350
like unique IDs and stuff like this.

517
00:24:53.350 --> 00:24:54.660
Now, do you have to do this?

518
00:24:54.660 --> 00:24:57.895
Do you have to make this more of a generic
image to apply to those different

519
00:24:57.895 --> 00:24:58.437
machines?

520
00:24:58.437 --> 00:24:59.730
>> No, you don't.

521
00:24:59.730 --> 00:25:04.045
So the question is kinda centering on
Sysprep, which is a Microsoft utility.

522
00:25:04.045 --> 00:25:06.250
>> Mm-hm.
>> In the Microsoft Windows world,

523
00:25:06.250 --> 00:25:10.650
every Windows installation that
you do has this unique identifier.

524
00:25:10.650 --> 00:25:12.680
It's called a SID, a security identifier.

525
00:25:12.680 --> 00:25:15.120
Every machine has one,
every user account has one.

526
00:25:15.120 --> 00:25:18.940
And if you clone a machine in
the Windows world and you have

527
00:25:18.940 --> 00:25:22.600
two machines with the same security
identifier, it causes a lot of problems.

528
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:24.579
So for you network admins that
are out there that work with Windows,

529
00:25:24.579 --> 00:25:26.380
you know that, you're familiar with that.

530
00:25:26.380 --> 00:25:30.214
Well, remember that Mac OS
under the hood is running BSD,

531
00:25:30.214 --> 00:25:31.940
it's running a flavor of Unix.

532
00:25:31.940 --> 00:25:36.440
And in the Unix world, you don't have
a unique identifier for your computer.

533
00:25:36.440 --> 00:25:41.390
You can have 1,000 machines built
off of the same exact image, and

534
00:25:41.390 --> 00:25:42.230
it doesn't matter.

535
00:25:42.230 --> 00:25:43.630
It doesn't affect things.

536
00:25:43.630 --> 00:25:48.830
It can be a little hairy if you have 1,000
machines all at the same name, right,

537
00:25:48.830 --> 00:25:50.170
and Apple won't let you do that.

538
00:25:50.170 --> 00:25:52.670
That if I deploy multiple
machines with the same name,

539
00:25:52.670 --> 00:25:54.050
they'll automatically rename themselves.

540
00:25:54.050 --> 00:25:56.320
And you might have seen this,
there was a bug.

541
00:25:56.320 --> 00:25:57.830
Let me see if my laptop has hit it.

542
00:25:57.830 --> 00:26:01.500
There was a bug in the earliest versions
of El Capitan, where your machine would

543
00:26:01.500 --> 00:26:06.900
boot up, and like, my machine is
called I think DPLAPTOP-OSX, right?

544
00:26:06.900 --> 00:26:11.930
So if I go into my System Preferences,
and I go into

545
00:26:11.930 --> 00:26:16.960
Sharing, so I'm in my System Preferences,
and I'm gonna go into Sharing.

546
00:26:16.960 --> 00:26:20.000
So right here,
you can see the name on my laptop, okay?

547
00:26:20.000 --> 00:26:23.400
If there was another machine on
the network with the same name,

548
00:26:24.410 --> 00:26:29.030
the second device to come up
would rename itself like that.

549
00:26:29.030 --> 00:26:31.610
And you might have seen this where
there's a parentheses and a one.

550
00:26:31.610 --> 00:26:35.590
And there was a bug in the earlier
versions of El Capitan, where

551
00:26:35.590 --> 00:26:39.240
like your laptop would see itself, thanks
to some DNS caching that was going on.

552
00:26:39.240 --> 00:26:42.370
And so my laptop was
incrementing like once a week.

553
00:26:42.370 --> 00:26:44.880
And I remember right before
I applied the last bug fix,

554
00:26:44.880 --> 00:26:51.110
I was at like DPLAPTOP-OSX 12, like it
renamed itself that many times as it went.

555
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:51.804
So that'll happen.

556
00:26:51.804 --> 00:26:55.307
So the reality is you can do an exact
bit for bit clone for a machine and

557
00:26:55.307 --> 00:26:58.212
roll it out 1,000 times,
and it doesn't matter.

558
00:26:58.212 --> 00:27:00.240
But in the net restore wizard,

559
00:27:00.240 --> 00:27:04.144
we had that option to randomize
the computer name, right.

560
00:27:04.144 --> 00:27:07.260
And I turned that on, I gave it a little
prefix and the rest of it's randomized.

561
00:27:07.260 --> 00:27:10.290
So the one thing that can cause
a problem is already taken care for

562
00:27:10.290 --> 00:27:10.834
us in the wizard.

563
00:27:10.834 --> 00:27:13.130
Yep, so that definitely makes life easy.

564
00:27:13.130 --> 00:27:16.000
It also makes life easier on like
software activations and stuff.

565
00:27:16.000 --> 00:27:18.660
Because in the Windows world,
when you run the Sysprep,

566
00:27:18.660 --> 00:27:21.630
all your software deactivates, and
you've gotta deal with all the licensing.

567
00:27:21.630 --> 00:27:22.510
Here, we don't, right?

568
00:27:22.510 --> 00:27:23.990
It's just that same machine.

569
00:27:25.480 --> 00:27:28.630
All right, so that restore image
is running in the background.

570
00:27:28.630 --> 00:27:32.730
And one thing you guys might notice
is that it's taking a lot longer

571
00:27:32.730 --> 00:27:33.780
than NetInstall did.

572
00:27:33.780 --> 00:27:36.290
Remember when we did NetInstall,
it went really fast.

573
00:27:36.290 --> 00:27:37.350
Why was that?

574
00:27:37.350 --> 00:27:41.650
Well, it had the El Capitan installer,
and that's what it uses as source, so

575
00:27:41.650 --> 00:27:43.870
it already had the source built.

576
00:27:43.870 --> 00:27:46.790
And it just needed to stick our automator
stuff on there, and it was done.

577
00:27:46.790 --> 00:27:50.370
But here,
it's gonna read that entire hard drive.

578
00:27:50.370 --> 00:27:54.420
It's gonna read all that data and
bring it over and that takes longer.

579
00:27:54.420 --> 00:27:56.530
And so it's gonna churn along and
do that, and

580
00:27:56.530 --> 00:27:59.950
when it's done,
we're going to have a net restore image.

581
00:27:59.950 --> 00:28:03.000
And the image itself really doesn't
look much different than the image

582
00:28:03.000 --> 00:28:04.820
that we did for net install earlier,

583
00:28:04.820 --> 00:28:07.290
the difference here being that it's
just got a lot of customizations in it.

584
00:28:07.290 --> 00:28:08.720
It's got a full install.

585
00:28:08.720 --> 00:28:10.910
And that's really
the power of net restore.

586
00:28:10.910 --> 00:28:11.590
>> Very good.

587
00:28:11.590 --> 00:28:14.380
So in this episode,
we've been looking at net restore and

588
00:28:14.380 --> 00:28:18.910
how you can use it to apply an image to
your machine, or well, 1,000 machines,

589
00:28:18.910 --> 00:28:20.730
depending on what your
deployment might be.

590
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:22.840
Don, have anything else for
us in this episode?

591
00:28:22.840 --> 00:28:24.850
>> Just a comment about
the source machine.

592
00:28:24.850 --> 00:28:27.720
That when we're done, we've got the image,
we're ready to go and

593
00:28:27.720 --> 00:28:29.440
deploy, what do we do
with the source machine?

594
00:28:29.440 --> 00:28:32.460
Well, you can boot it back up and
it's already got the image on it,

595
00:28:32.460 --> 00:28:33.850
cuz we used it as the source.

596
00:28:33.850 --> 00:28:35.310
So you can then turn it
loose to the wild and

597
00:28:35.310 --> 00:28:36.337
distribute it with your other machines.

598
00:28:36.337 --> 00:28:39.930
Or you could set it aside,
and you could say,

599
00:28:39.930 --> 00:28:42.886
hey, this is my dedicated source machine.

600
00:28:42.886 --> 00:28:45.520
And that's kind of useful cuz
there's one thing that I like to do,

601
00:28:45.520 --> 00:28:48.940
which is if you have a dedicated
source machine, once a week,

602
00:28:48.940 --> 00:28:51.420
you can log into it and
apply all the updates, right.

603
00:28:51.420 --> 00:28:55.845
Apply the app store updates, just the
operating system updates that come out,

604
00:28:55.845 --> 00:28:59.495
any software updates for
other applications you gotta install.

605
00:28:59.495 --> 00:29:00.640
You can just update it.

606
00:29:00.640 --> 00:29:03.060
And then take a new image and
we take a new image you updated so

607
00:29:03.060 --> 00:29:05.900
that you always know when you're deploying
that image, it's the most recent.

608
00:29:05.900 --> 00:29:09.020
So if you have a dedicated source machine,

609
00:29:09.020 --> 00:29:12.410
it makes it easier to do the continual
management of net restorer.

610
00:29:12.410 --> 00:29:16.377
If I send this net restorer machine out,
this is the source machine out to whoever,

611
00:29:16.377 --> 00:29:20.001
any end user to use it, any time I want
to update the image, I've got to go and

612
00:29:20.001 --> 00:29:20.814
get a computer.

613
00:29:20.814 --> 00:29:24.510
I've got to deploy the net restore
image that I made, update it, and

614
00:29:24.510 --> 00:29:27.360
take the image, so
it's extra steps involved.

615
00:29:27.360 --> 00:29:31.230
So if you can keep your source machine
as dedicated, that makes sense.

616
00:29:31.230 --> 00:29:33.030
But if you're on a shoestring budget,

617
00:29:33.030 --> 00:29:36.680
having a machine sitting there doing
nothing most of the time is not great.

618
00:29:36.680 --> 00:29:39.630
So, that may not be an option,
and you would just have to go and

619
00:29:39.630 --> 00:29:42.470
redeploy the net restore image to
make your changes and reimage it.

620
00:29:42.470 --> 00:29:44.450
So, yeah, a little extra headache there.

621
00:29:44.450 --> 00:29:45.790
>> All right, Don, great information.

622
00:29:45.790 --> 00:29:50.160
We've got a lot more good information
to come in our Mac Management Basics.

623
00:29:50.160 --> 00:29:53.000
But looks like we're coming to the end
of this one, so we're gonna go ahead and

624
00:29:53.000 --> 00:29:54.440
sign out for ITProTV.

625
00:29:54.440 --> 00:29:56.210
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

626
00:29:56.210 --> 00:29:56.734
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

627
00:29:56.734 --> 00:29:57.960
>> And we'll see you next time.

628
00:29:57.960 --> 00:30:06.490
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don talk about how to deploy images to computers using removable media, specifically USB thumb drives. They also discuss the pro's and con's of using removable media to deploy and provision machine inside of a network.
episodes.title: Deploying via USB
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.086 --> 00:00:10.086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.181 --> 00:00:15.138
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.138 --> 00:00:16.403
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.403 --> 00:00:17.591
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:17.591 --> 00:00:20.645
were gonna be continuing along
in our Mac management basics.

6
00:00:20.645 --> 00:00:24.245
And joining me in the studio today is
a man that makes the geniuses look

7
00:00:24.245 --> 00:00:24.895
like fools.

8
00:00:24.895 --> 00:00:26.038
Yes, that's Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.038 --> 00:00:27.177
How are you doing, Don?

10
00:00:27.177 --> 00:00:29.105
>> Why do you gotta build me
up on such a pedestal, Wes?

11
00:00:29.105 --> 00:00:30.295
Now I get to disappoint for 30 minutes.

12
00:00:30.295 --> 00:00:33.117
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I am glad to be back though.

13
00:00:33.117 --> 00:00:36.730
We're gonna jump right back
into Mac management basics.

14
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:41.800
And I know some of you out there
are saying, all right, this Don guy,

15
00:00:41.800 --> 00:00:43.040
he showed us how to do a lot of stuff.

16
00:00:43.040 --> 00:00:45.330
The last three episodes
we built a lot of images.

17
00:00:45.330 --> 00:00:47.040
But what have we done with those images?

18
00:00:47.040 --> 00:00:48.450
What have those images done for us lately?

19
00:00:48.450 --> 00:00:49.450
And the answer is nothing, right?

20
00:00:49.450 --> 00:00:51.840
We haven't used the images at all.

21
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:55.230
And so, in our next two episodes what
we're gonna do is we're gonna focus on

22
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:58.100
using those images,
deploying them back out.

23
00:00:58.100 --> 00:01:02.468
And when it comes to deploying NetInstall,
NetRestore restore, even NetBoot, well,

24
00:01:02.468 --> 00:01:04.227
I guess to a lesser extent NetBoot.

25
00:01:04.227 --> 00:01:08.520
With NetInstall and NetRestore,
there's two ways to really deploy them.

26
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:11.890
There's via removable media,
or via the network.

27
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:14.730
Now, via the network, that's the way that
you really wanna do it in a business or

28
00:01:14.730 --> 00:01:15.750
corporate environment.

29
00:01:15.750 --> 00:01:18.110
But sometimes you don't have
the infrastructure in place.

30
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:20.990
And so, removable media is
another great way to do it.

31
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:21.950
So, we've got both options.

32
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:25.310
And when I say removable media,
it's not just any old media.

33
00:01:25.310 --> 00:01:28.010
You used to be able to get
DVDs to install and so on.

34
00:01:28.010 --> 00:01:29.720
Now, it's pretty much just USB keys.

35
00:01:29.720 --> 00:01:33.420
So, if you have a USB key, or
a USB hard drive of some sort,

36
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:38.360
you can use that to boot your system and
do an install off of it and go from there.

37
00:01:38.360 --> 00:01:42.150
So, the one that doesn't quite
work with both is NetBoot.

38
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:45.320
Because NetBoot, by definition you're
supposed to be booting your computer from

39
00:01:45.320 --> 00:01:50.340
the network, not booting from
a USB key attached to your system.

40
00:01:50.340 --> 00:01:53.180
But there is actually a way to get
NetBoot to work from a USB key,

41
00:01:53.180 --> 00:01:55.390
it just kind of defeats
the whole purpose of it, right?

42
00:01:55.390 --> 00:02:00.080
So, when we go to a Mac and we wanna
deploy an image, we've got choices.

43
00:02:00.080 --> 00:02:03.200
And the reality is you'll probably
use both, a mixture of both.

44
00:02:03.200 --> 00:02:05.170
You'll use the network when
it's available, but if for

45
00:02:05.170 --> 00:02:06.730
some reason the network isn't available,

46
00:02:06.730 --> 00:02:09.310
you'll want USB keys available too,
all right?

47
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:12.020
So, in this episode we're gonna
tackle that USB side of things.

48
00:02:12.020 --> 00:02:16.990
So, let's say that I need to deploy
El Capitan out to my systems and

49
00:02:16.990 --> 00:02:18.890
I wanna do it with a USB key.

50
00:02:18.890 --> 00:02:21.730
Okay, well, in our NetInstall episodes,

51
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:24.280
we built some images for
installing El Capitan.

52
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:28.450
And we built one that was just
a stock image of El Capitan.

53
00:02:28.450 --> 00:02:30.660
And then,
we built one that was customized,

54
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:32.600
that had a lot of modifications to it.

55
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:33.710

If this was our NetInstall image,
and it was the stock El Capitan,

499
00:24:23.270 --> 00:24:26.110
it would just be copying that hard
drive and that's the end of it.

500
00:24:26.110 --> 00:24:29.130
If it was our customized NetInstall image,

501
00:24:29.130 --> 00:24:34.370
it would copy the install over and then
it would run through the Automator steps.

502
00:24:34.370 --> 00:24:37.770
And remember, we had Automator steps
that installed VirtualBox, right, and

503
00:24:37.770 --> 00:24:39.750
set the power saving settings on.

504
00:24:39.750 --> 00:24:42.250
It would run through each of
those after it copies over.

505
00:24:42.250 --> 00:24:44.962
But, basically,
at this point you get to sit here and

506
00:24:44.962 --> 00:24:48.535
watch the status bar creep across
the green screen slowly and slowly.

507
00:24:48.535 --> 00:24:51.188
My image is about nine gigs in size.

508
00:24:51.188 --> 00:24:54.743
So copying nine gigs on a USB 3 disk
will take probably four or five minutes.

509
00:24:54.743 --> 00:24:57.136
So we can let that churn along.

510
00:24:57.136 --> 00:25:01.390
If you really have big image though, let's
say your image is 200 gigs and you've got

511
00:25:01.390 --> 00:25:05.145
it on an external USB hard drive, and
you hook it up, this could take an hour.

512
00:25:05.145 --> 00:25:06.740
It could take two hours, right?

513
00:25:06.740 --> 00:25:09.530
And that's not a big deal if
you're just restoring one machine.

514
00:25:09.530 --> 00:25:12.560
But what if I have 1,000
machines to restore?

515
00:25:12.560 --> 00:25:16.040
I take my one little USB key and
I go to the first machine and I start it.

516
00:25:16.040 --> 00:25:17.570
I come back two hours from now.

517
00:25:17.570 --> 00:25:21.370
And then I take that USB key and I come
back to the second one, and I restart it.

518
00:25:21.370 --> 00:25:22.660
And then the third one,
and the fourth one.

519
00:25:22.660 --> 00:25:25.820
I can only do one at a time cuz
I've only got one USB disk.

520
00:25:25.820 --> 00:25:26.840
So what are my options?

521
00:25:26.840 --> 00:25:29.180
Well, I could buy a lot more USB disks.

522
00:25:29.180 --> 00:25:29.888
We could do that.

523
00:25:29.888 --> 00:25:30.799
I got 1,000 computers.

524
00:25:30.799 --> 00:25:35.097
I could buy 1,000 USB keys and plug one
into each computer, boot them all holding

525
00:25:35.097 --> 00:25:39.590
the alt key, and choose that USB key,
and now my 1,000 machines are done.

526
00:25:39.590 --> 00:25:41.890
Honestly, it's not so bad, right?

527
00:25:41.890 --> 00:25:43.140
You gotta build 1,000 USB keys.

528
00:25:43.140 --> 00:25:46.080
That's not any fun, but it does work.

529
00:25:46.080 --> 00:25:48.270
But the better option would be to say,

530
00:25:48.270 --> 00:25:50.620
let's just do this over the network,
instead.

531
00:25:50.620 --> 00:25:54.150
Over the network, I don't need all
these USB keys any more, right?

532
00:25:54.150 --> 00:25:58.550
I can boot from the network resource, and
I can load the NBI from the network, and

533
00:25:58.550 --> 00:25:59.940
pull it that way.

534
00:25:59.940 --> 00:26:02.790
And now I don't have to have all of
these USB keys that are out there.

535
00:26:02.790 --> 00:26:03.560
I mean you can still do it.

536
00:26:03.560 --> 00:26:06.370
You can still put the USB keys in,
and go that route if you want.

537
00:26:06.370 --> 00:26:10.180
If you're doing one, or five, or
ten, the USB keys work great.

538
00:26:10.180 --> 00:26:14.330
But if you were doing 1,000, the network
deployment's gonna be the better option.

539
00:26:14.330 --> 00:26:17.200
So I'm just kinda stalling
while this finishes.

540
00:26:17.200 --> 00:26:18.760
So what we've seen here in this episode,

541
00:26:18.760 --> 00:26:22.670
we built a USB key that was a stock,
OS X El Capitan installer.

542
00:26:22.670 --> 00:26:24.570
We built that right from
the installation app.

543
00:26:25.610 --> 00:26:30.020
We copied a NetRestore image,
identical for NetInstall.

544
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:33.170
You would copy it over,
cuz it doesn't really care what it is.

545
00:26:33.170 --> 00:26:34.630
And then we saw blessing that folder.

546
00:26:34.630 --> 00:26:35.810
That's really important to set that.

547
00:26:35.810 --> 00:26:37.280
There will be a question
on the exam about that.

548
00:26:37.280 --> 00:26:39.460
There always is about
blessing that folder.

549
00:26:39.460 --> 00:26:42.750
And then after that,
we just boot off the USB key, and we go.

550
00:26:42.750 --> 00:26:46.180
Once you boot off the USB key, it really
doesn't matter where that image came from.

551
00:26:46.180 --> 00:26:47.780
It all deploy its kind of the same way.

552
00:26:47.780 --> 00:26:50.060
It's gonna churn along,
and then it'll be done.

553
00:26:50.060 --> 00:26:54.910
Now, when this finishes, the systems gonna
reboot, and I'm done with the USB key.

554
00:26:54.910 --> 00:26:56.190
I can take it out, and

555
00:26:56.190 --> 00:27:00.330
now I've got a machine with built
exactly around that NetRestore image.

556
00:27:00.330 --> 00:27:02.780
Alright, let's check on our progress and
see where we're at on this one.

557
00:27:02.780 --> 00:27:04.050
Looks like it's almost done.

558
00:27:04.050 --> 00:27:09.590
Now what you'll see sometimes is where
it'll copy over files that are compressed,

559
00:27:09.590 --> 00:27:11.260
and then it's gotta decompress them.

560
00:27:11.260 --> 00:27:14.040
So sometimes this last step
can take a little bit.

561
00:27:14.040 --> 00:27:18.120
So our status bar, that we just
saw reach all the way to the side,

562
00:27:18.120 --> 00:27:20.600
now it jumps back to the beginning
as it starts to decompress.

563
00:27:20.600 --> 00:27:24.100
And again, our image is small,
should happen pretty fast.

564
00:27:24.100 --> 00:27:28.420
But once it's done,
we'll have our good system ready to go.

565
00:27:28.420 --> 00:27:30.840
All right, well, I make this comment Wes,

566
00:27:30.840 --> 00:27:35.650
that I've spent a good 50% of my career
watching bars like these scroll across

567
00:27:35.650 --> 00:27:39.590
the screen, and
it's better than digging a ditch.

568
00:27:39.590 --> 00:27:41.360
>> It certainly is [LAUGH].

569
00:27:41.360 --> 00:27:45.600
I think, one time, you told me 30% of
your IT career is waiting for a reboot.

570
00:27:45.600 --> 00:27:48.870
>> Those are all the kind of
things that fall into this.

571
00:27:48.870 --> 00:27:53.060
Fortunately, it's all automated, and
it could have been much more involved.

572
00:27:53.060 --> 00:27:56.600
If I'd done the stock installer,
it has to do all sorts of things.

573
00:27:56.600 --> 00:28:00.380
You have to give it a user name, you pick
a password, you pick the icon for your

574
00:28:00.380 --> 00:28:04.400
account, you pick what drive to install,
you sign off on the licensing agreement.

575
00:28:04.400 --> 00:28:07.240
All of those are things that
happen during that process.

576
00:28:07.240 --> 00:28:09.460
But here, I didn't tell it a single thing.

577
00:28:09.460 --> 00:28:12.280
I just booted off the USB key,
and then walked away.

578
00:28:12.280 --> 00:28:15.540
And now it's done, and
it's actually booting from the hard drive.

579
00:28:15.540 --> 00:28:17.190
Right?
And I didn't have to tell it to do that.

580
00:28:17.190 --> 00:28:18.140
It's doing it on it's own.

581
00:28:18.140 --> 00:28:19.510
It's gonna move through that, and

582
00:28:19.510 --> 00:28:22.020
it's gonna get everything put
back the way that I want it.

583
00:28:22.020 --> 00:28:25.320
So now it's booting it, and
you guy's cant see this the way I can,

584
00:28:25.320 --> 00:28:26.940
but I'm looking at the USB key here.

585
00:28:26.940 --> 00:28:28.850
It's got a little red light
that flashes when it's reading,

586
00:28:28.850 --> 00:28:30.140
and it's not flashing, right?

587
00:28:30.140 --> 00:28:32.410
We're not reading from the USB
key at all at this point.

588
00:28:32.410 --> 00:28:34.530
It's booting from the hard drive.

589
00:28:34.530 --> 00:28:35.900
And when we're done,

590
00:28:35.900 --> 00:28:39.080
we'll end up with a system whose
resolution might not be right.

591
00:28:39.080 --> 00:28:40.390
We'll see here in a second.

592
00:28:40.390 --> 00:28:42.475
I got a little black screen coming up.

593
00:28:42.475 --> 00:28:45.300
It can reboot a few times,
depending on what it's doing.

594
00:28:45.300 --> 00:28:46.920
So it might actually have
to go into one more reboot.

595
00:28:46.920 --> 00:28:50.500
And then when it's done, we'll be greeted
with our El Capitan installer cuz it has

596
00:28:50.500 --> 00:28:52.098
to do a few things in the background.

597
00:28:52.098 --> 00:28:54.118
There's like Automator steps,
and stuff that goes on.

598
00:28:54.118 --> 00:28:56.463
All right, actually,
looks like it finished booting.

599
00:28:56.463 --> 00:28:59.169
So I'm now booted up,
I'm on my Mac screen, and, honestly,

600
00:28:59.169 --> 00:29:03.410
I should have unplugged my USB key before,
but I'm not running from the USB key.

601
00:29:03.410 --> 00:29:07.720
And I can get logged into this thing and
what I should see when I log in,

602
00:29:07.720 --> 00:29:12.865
I'm gonna fill my IT should in there,
is that we're running El Capitan, and

603
00:29:12.865 --> 00:29:14.010
that it's setup the way we want.

604
00:29:14.010 --> 00:29:17.020
Already I can see we've got
the space wallpaper instead of

605
00:29:17.020 --> 00:29:20.750
the shadowy mountains, or wherever
that we normally have with El Capitan.

606
00:29:20.750 --> 00:29:25.670
And as it gets in, what I expect to see
is Google Cyber Docs, Google Chrome,

607
00:29:25.670 --> 00:29:26.910
and sure enough there they are.

608
00:29:26.910 --> 00:29:28.950
So I've got the applications
that I wanted,

609
00:29:28.950 --> 00:29:32.060
they're already there,
iBooks is out of the dock, right?

610
00:29:32.060 --> 00:29:35.630
All those other things that get in there
that get in the way of my end users,

611
00:29:35.630 --> 00:29:38.498
those are all gone, and
we're up, and we're running.

612
00:29:38.498 --> 00:29:40.070
It's pretty slick stuff.

613
00:29:40.070 --> 00:29:43.970
So I could take this, this USB key right
here, and go to as many machines as I

614
00:29:43.970 --> 00:29:48.700
want, and create this exact system,
that has the software,

615
00:29:48.700 --> 00:29:51.620
the configuration settings,
everything in place, and off we go.

616
00:29:51.620 --> 00:29:54.670
In fact, the only thing that
really got randomized on this

617
00:29:54.670 --> 00:29:55.850
would be the computer name.

618
00:29:55.850 --> 00:29:59.550
So if I jump into System Preferences,
and go into Sharing, I told it,

619
00:29:59.550 --> 00:30:01.370
you know honestly I don't remember.

620
00:30:01.370 --> 00:30:04.600
I think I told it to prefix
it with the word lab, and

621
00:30:04.600 --> 00:30:07.620
then add a random string to the end
of it when we were in that wizard.

622
00:30:07.620 --> 00:30:09.670
I probably should have
paid more attention.

623
00:30:09.670 --> 00:30:12.655
And if I look at it, sure enough,
I can see where it says lab, and

624
00:30:12.655 --> 00:30:15.600
then it's followed by kind
of a random mess there.

625
00:30:15.600 --> 00:30:17.620
So it's given it that unique name, but

626
00:30:17.620 --> 00:30:20.890
everything else is exactly
as that image was built.

627
00:30:20.890 --> 00:30:24.190
This guy is ready to be distributed
to my end users or whoever.

628
00:30:24.190 --> 00:30:25.090
>> Great information.

629
00:30:25.090 --> 00:30:28.370
Now in this episode, keep in mind, that
we've been looking at how you can deploy

630
00:30:28.370 --> 00:30:31.980
your operating system with removable
media, typically a USB device, and

631
00:30:31.980 --> 00:30:33.540
how to format that USB device.

632
00:30:33.540 --> 00:30:34.420
Great information Don.

633
00:30:34.420 --> 00:30:36.040
Got anything else for us in this one?

634
00:30:36.040 --> 00:30:39.810
Well, remember that the USB stuff sure is
convenient, but it doesn't work at scale.

635
00:30:39.810 --> 00:30:41.980
And so in the next episode we're
gonna see the same thing, but

636
00:30:41.980 --> 00:30:43.670
by using a NetInstall server.

637
00:30:43.670 --> 00:30:46.720
So we're gonna do it over the network,
and that's the far cooler way to do it.

638
00:30:46.720 --> 00:30:48.290
So you'll definitely wanna tune in for
that one.

639
00:30:48.290 --> 00:30:49.370
>> Great information.

640
00:30:49.370 --> 00:30:54.180
So much more exciting content to come
in our Mac Management Basics but

641
00:30:54.180 --> 00:30:56.260
we're gonna go ahead and
sign out for this episode.

642
00:30:56.260 --> 00:30:57.390
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

643
00:30:57.390 --> 00:30:58.410
>> And I'm Don Pazet.

644
00:30:58.410 --> 00:31:00.098
>> And we'll see you next time.

645
00:31:00.098 --> 00:31:07.930
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don dive into deployment of OS X El Capitan images to machines over the network. They will demonstrate how to setup and build the NetInstall server that will be used to deploy the operating systems to the devices inisde of the local area network as well as connecting the client machine to the server to obtain the EL Capitan OS image.
episodes.title: Deploying via Network
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.066 --> 00:00:10.066
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.116 --> 00:00:15.134
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.134 --> 00:00:16.227
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.227 --> 00:00:20.005
And in today's episode, we're gonna be
moving through Mac management basics.

5
00:00:20.005 --> 00:00:22.635
And we've got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet here to help us out.

6
00:00:22.635 --> 00:00:24.075
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:24.075 --> 00:00:24.925
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:24.925 --> 00:00:28.405
Ready to jump right back into
the world of deploying Mac OS over,

9
00:00:28.405 --> 00:00:30.837
well, whatever system it is
that we're gonna be doing.

10
00:00:30.837 --> 00:00:33.773
In our last episode, we got a chance
to see how to deploy our NetInstall and

11
00:00:33.773 --> 00:00:37.390
NetRestore images by using USB keys or
removable media.

12
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:39.180
In this episode,
we're gonna do the fun one,

13
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:43.090
which is deploying those same images but
doing it via the network,

14
00:00:43.090 --> 00:00:46.160
which is far more efficient when you've
got a large quantity of systems.

15
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.350
So, still working with those
same NetInstall, same NetRestore

16
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:53.610
images as before but this time,
we're gonna send them over the network.

17
00:00:53.610 --> 00:00:56.280
And that means we don't need
those removable keys any more and

18
00:00:56.280 --> 00:00:58.710
we get a much more scalable solution.

19
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:00.150
All right, well let's kick things off.

20
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:03.150
I just kinda wanna start by identifying
the differences here cuz what we're about

21
00:01:03.150 --> 00:01:05.440
to do is actually very similar to
what we did in the last episode.

22
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:10.310
In the last episode, we took a Mac Mini,
and I stuck a USB key in it and

23
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:14.070
that USB key had my
NetRestore image on it.

24
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:16.040
And it was blessed so
that it would boot and

25
00:01:16.040 --> 00:01:18.970
we got a chance to see booting
up off that USB key, and

26
00:01:18.970 --> 00:01:22.650
I did that by holding down the Alt key
on that client while we turned it on.

27
00:01:22.650 --> 00:01:24.380
And it showed the USB key.

28
00:01:24.380 --> 00:01:25.030
We booted from it.

29
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:27.080
And then it automatically installed OS X.

30
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:28.540
And we were up and running in short order.

31
00:01:28.540 --> 00:01:31.950
I think the whole process took less
than ten minutes to get that Mac

32
00:01:31.950 --> 00:01:33.140
deployed and ready to rock.

33
00:01:33.140 --> 00:01:37.120
Okay and that worked fine,
except for that USB key part, right?

34
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:38.170
The fact that I got to have a key.

35
00:01:38.170 --> 00:01:38.990
And the comment I made in

36
00:01:38.990 --> 00:01:41.460
the last episode was this works
great if I have one machine.

37
00:01:41.460 --> 00:01:44.530
But what if I wanna do
1000 machines at once?

38
00:01:44.530 --> 00:01:48.784
Well, if I want to do them all at the same
time I would need 1000 USB keys and

39
00:01:48.784 --> 00:01:50.623
that's just not ideal, right.

40
00:01:50.623 --> 00:01:52.661
I don't want to have to go out and
get all this different,

41
00:01:52.661 --> 00:01:54.161
these different USB keys laying around.

42
00:01:54.161 --> 00:01:57.211
So by setting up
a centralized network server,

43
00:01:57.211 --> 00:02:01.341
we can take this a step further and
make things a lot more simple.

44
00:02:01.341 --> 00:02:05.772
When our Macs boot up, you can tell
them not to boot from a USB key but

45
00:02:05.772 --> 00:02:08.080
instead to boot from the network.

46
00:02:08.080 --> 00:02:11.194
And when they boot from the network,
they'll look out at the network and

47
00:02:11.194 --> 00:02:13.607
they'll look for
what's called a NetInstall server.

48
00:02:13.607 --> 00:02:17.304
And a NetInstall server is just a Mac
somewhere on your network that's

49
00:02:17.304 --> 00:02:21.610
holding a copy of your images and
making them available via the network.

50
00:02:21.610 --> 00:02:26.113
And so I can boot 1000 machines to
the network without using USB key.

51
00:02:26.113 --> 00:02:29.922
And they find a NetInstall server where I
can have all my images stored right there

52
00:02:29.922 --> 00:02:31.050
and we can boot from it.

53
00:02:31.050 --> 00:02:35.550
And if I decide to update my images,
I just update them on the server.

54
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:39.087
And now when I start deploying, we'll
be deploying the new image versus if I

55
00:02:39.087 --> 00:02:42.858
had made 1000 USB keys, and I decide to
update my image, what do I have to do?

56
00:02:42.858 --> 00:02:44.553
I'm gonna update a 1000 USB keys.

57
00:02:44.553 --> 00:02:45.465
That's not realistic.

58
00:02:45.465 --> 00:02:46.780
Nobody is gonna do that.

59
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:48.015
Unless you're an hourly employee.

60
00:02:48.015 --> 00:02:51.660
[LAUGH] And you're trying to justify your
budget, whatever it is, maybe there.

61
00:02:51.660 --> 00:02:54.010
But realistically,
nobody's gonna do that, right?

62
00:02:54.010 --> 00:02:56.330
So the NetInstall server
is really the way to go.

63
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:01.190
And what I always tell people is for me,
if it's five computers, ten computers, and

64
00:03:01.190 --> 00:03:03.208
I'm just doing this deployment one time.

65
00:03:03.208 --> 00:03:07.910
I'll use NetRestore, I'll do boots
off of a USB and I'll go that route.

66
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:11.070
But if it's gonna be hundreds or
thousands of machines and

67
00:03:11.070 --> 00:03:14.460
I'm not just doing it one time,
I'm gonna be doing this periodically and

68
00:03:14.460 --> 00:03:18.880
the images have to update, I'm gonna
do NetInstall and NetInstall Servers.

69
00:03:18.880 --> 00:03:22.243
Right, so NetInstall images cuz
they're really easy to update and

70
00:03:22.243 --> 00:03:25.470
a NetInstall Server so
I can make it available via the network.

71
00:03:25.470 --> 00:03:27.580
Now what we're gonna see in this episode,

72
00:03:27.580 --> 00:03:29.630
I'm gonna show you guys how to
set up a NetInstall server.

73
00:03:29.630 --> 00:03:31.620
And I'm gonna call it that

individual machines or all computers.
