topics.title: Managing Mac Computers with Apple Remote Desktop

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at policy-based management through Apple's One Directory. They talk about the benefits to using a directory such as Open Directory such as centralized user database management, centralized user account and password management. They explain the differences between and Open Directory Master server versus and Open Directory Replica server.
episodes.title: Open Directory
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.045 --> 00:00:14.871
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.871 --> 00:00:16.680
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:20.020
in today's episode we're moving
through our Mac management basics.

5
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:22.380
We got non other than Mr. Don Pezet here.

6
00:00:22.380 --> 00:00:23.530
Don, how you doing Sir?

7
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:24.470
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

8
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:27.530
ready to jump right back into
the world of Mac management basics.

9
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:28.450
And in this episode,

10
00:00:28.450 --> 00:00:31.300
we're actually gonna go a little
bit off the exam objective track.

11
00:00:31.300 --> 00:00:34.210
So normally we make our episodes
where they really do align with

12
00:00:34.210 --> 00:00:36.490
the exam objectives so
you learn everything you need to do.

13
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:40.080
The next thing that's coming
up is the profile manager and

14
00:00:40.080 --> 00:00:42.650
it's a really important tool,
there's a lot of ins and outs of it, so

15
00:00:42.650 --> 00:00:44.450
we wanna spend some time on it.

16
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:48.740
But you can't deploy the profile
manager without having a good

17
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:53.730
Open Directory set up and open directory
is not technically on the exam objectives.

18
00:00:53.730 --> 00:00:55.460
But if you don't know how to set it up,

19
00:00:55.460 --> 00:00:57.220
it's kind of hard to get
the profile manager working.

20
00:00:57.220 --> 00:01:00.580
So I wanted to spend a little extra time,
and just go off the beaten path and

21
00:01:00.580 --> 00:01:04.310
take a look at open directory and how
it works, and how we can get it set up.

22
00:01:04.310 --> 00:01:06.776
Now, if you've never heard of
the Open Directory before,

23
00:01:06.776 --> 00:01:09.740
let me just start off really
basic here with the heck it is.

24
00:01:09.740 --> 00:01:13.112
Normally, when you set up a Mac, you
create a user account with that Mac, so

25
00:01:13.112 --> 00:01:15.660
that you can log in to it and
work with it.

26
00:01:15.660 --> 00:01:18.650
Well, if you get up,
walk across your office and

27
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:22.775
sit down somebody else's computer,
can you log in with that account?

28
00:01:22.775 --> 00:01:25.170
No, accounts on a Mac
are local by default.

29
00:01:25.170 --> 00:01:26.020
They're local accounts, and

30
00:01:26.020 --> 00:01:29.990
that means they only work on the computer
they're created on, and that's it.

31
00:01:29.990 --> 00:01:31.510
And for a home user, that's fine,

32
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:33.980
or if you have a dedicated computer,
that's fine.

33
00:01:33.980 --> 00:01:34.520
But in an office,

34
00:01:34.520 --> 00:01:38.220
where you might have hundreds or thousands
of computers, in an environment where

35
00:01:38.220 --> 00:01:40.830
you have shared computers where
more than one person uses it.

36
00:01:40.830 --> 00:01:43.300
It starts to become really
challenging to manage and

37
00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:48.190
maintain those local accounts and so
what Open Directory does is it creates

38
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:53.610
a centralized database, one big place
when we create our user accounts.

39
00:01:53.610 --> 00:01:59.290
And then I can log in on any Mac in my
company using the exact same user account.

40
00:01:59.290 --> 00:02:02.610
So centralized user account database,
that's what Open Directory is all about.

41
00:02:02.610 --> 00:02:05.080
And Open Directory's not the only
solution that's out there,

42
00:02:05.080 --> 00:02:07.430
there's a ton of them, but
this is the one that's from Apple.

43
00:02:07.430 --> 00:02:09.440
So in this episode we're gonna
get a chance to see how to set up

44
00:02:09.440 --> 00:02:11.719
the Open Directory and
just kind of see it in action.

45
00:02:12.800 --> 00:02:14.780
Now when it comes to deploying this,

46
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:17.780
there are a few things that we need to be
aware of, some little basic knowledge that

47
00:02:17.780 --> 00:02:21.900
we need to have, and it could be that
you don't even need Open Directory.

48
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:24.710
And what I mean by that is you may
already have a directory service in

49
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:25.660
your environment.

50
00:02:25.660 --> 00:02:28.010
You don't have to have
Apple's Open Directory.

51
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:31.030
You could use
Microsoft's Active Directory, for example.

52
00:02:31.030 --> 00:02:33.150
That's very prominent out
there in the business world.

53
00:02:33.150 --> 00:02:34.220
If you want to learn more about that one,

54
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:36.630
we're gonna cover it in the Mac
integration basic series.

55
00:02:36.630 --> 00:02:40.670
That's where we focus on integrating Macs
with Windows, so we'll see it more there.

56
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:42.413
Here, I wanted to focus
on the Apple side of it,

57
00:02:42.413 --> 00:02:45.310
because this is Mac management basics,
not Windows management basics.

58
00:02:45.310 --> 00:02:47.610
So, we're going to take
a look at the Open Directory.

59
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:51.970
But Open Directory is actually very
similar to Microsoft's Active Directory.

60
00:02:51.970 --> 00:02:55.620
They both work with an underlying
protocol called LDAP.

61
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:59.210
And LDAP is
the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.

62
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:02.510
It's an open standard that
anybody can use, and as you see,

63
00:03:02.510 --> 00:03:06.800
most people are, that allows you to
have a database with user accounts and

64
00:03:06.800 --> 00:03:09.700
then your clients can query that database.

65
00:03:09.700 --> 00:03:12.980
So when your computer boots up and
asks for a username it's not looking for

66
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:16.640
a local user name, it's looking for
one in a database across the network.

67
00:03:16.640 --> 00:03:19.990
And it uses LDAP to reach out to that
server to ask it that question and say,

68
00:03:19.990 --> 00:03:23.640
hey, I just got a username and
password, is this valid?

69
00:03:23.640 --> 00:03:24.360
>> Very good, Don.

70
00:03:24.360 --> 00:03:27.750
One of the things that we know
about like the Macintosh or

71
00:03:27.750 --> 00:03:32.540
Mac systems is that under the hood as
you've shown us with the terminal and

72
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:34.010
everything they're Unix based, right?

73
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:37.490
So they spring off of an operating
system that's been around there for

74
00:03:37.490 --> 00:03:38.695
a long time now.

75
00:03:38.695 --> 00:03:41.735
Open Directory's got some
similarity to that, right?

76
00:03:41.735 --> 00:03:44.885
It springs off of an underlying
technology as well, right?

77
00:03:44.885 --> 00:03:46.705
>> Yeah,
Apple didn't write this one from scratch.

78
00:03:46.705 --> 00:03:49.615
And most of the server apps aren't written
from scratch, some of them are, but

79
00:03:49.615 --> 00:03:50.875
most of them aren't.

80
00:03:50.875 --> 00:03:53.860
Open Directory is one of
those where it isn't.

81
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:55.830
In the open source world,
like in the Linux and

82
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.920
Unix world,
there's a product called Open LDAP.

83
00:03:58.920 --> 00:04:02.320
And it's just a open source Lightweight
Directory Access Protocol Server,

84
00:04:02.320 --> 00:04:03.690
an open LDAP server.

85
00:04:03.690 --> 00:04:07.090
And so when Apple created their directory,
they just took Open LDAP and

86
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:08.660
modified it to suit their needs.

87
00:04:08.660 --> 00:04:10.550
They call that forking the software.

88
00:04:10.550 --> 00:04:14.630
So they split it off the main Open LDAP
project and created Open Directory.

89
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:17.400
Now what they've ended up with is

90
00:04:17.400 --> 00:04:19.230
something that's now
technically proprietary.

91
00:04:19.230 --> 00:04:22.490
Active Directory is
proprietary to Microsoft,

92
00:04:22.490 --> 00:04:24.782
Open Directory is proprietary to Apple.

93
00:04:24.782 --> 00:04:27.350
Open LDAP, that's an open standard,

94
00:04:27.350 --> 00:04:30.820
you can run it anywhere and
it's not proprietary to anybody.

95
00:04:30.820 --> 00:04:32.970
Now all three of them
are compatible though.

96
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:35.754
You can actually get all three of
them to talk to each other and

97
00:04:35.754 --> 00:04:39.300
they work just fine because deep down
under the hood all through using the LDAP

98
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:42.212
protocols or using standards
based communications, right?

99
00:04:42.212 --> 00:04:46.685
We have LDAP for doing our lookup or
Kerberos or Kerberos or however you want

100
00:04:46.685 --> 00:04:50.805
to say it for doing authentication
which Microsoft uses by default,

101
00:04:50.805 --> 00:04:54.460
Apple uses by default, and
Open LDAP makes use of also.

102
00:04:54.460 --> 00:04:58.620
So it's all nice and
standards based, makes it kinda easy.

103
00:04:58.620 --> 00:05:01.570
So when we turn on Open Directory
on our Apple machines,

104
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:04.530
what we're actually doing in
the background is turning on a modified

105
00:05:04.530 --> 00:05:06.490
version of Open LDAP,
that's where this all stems from.

106
00:05:07.660 --> 00:05:10.780
All right, now one of the biggest
advantages of doing this,

107
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:13.390
cuz some of you guys might be asking
about that right now, thinking well,

108
00:05:13.390 --> 00:05:15.070
Don, this sounds like a lot.

109
00:05:15.070 --> 00:05:16.240
I don't wanna mess with it.

110
00:05:16.240 --> 00:05:18.800
I can just create local accounts and
run that way, right?

111
00:05:18.800 --> 00:05:22.340
Let me give you a few scenarios where
this really, really makes it valuable.

112
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:27.194
Let's say you've got 1,000 computers and

113
00:05:27.194 --> 00:05:32.254
you're hiring a new person and
they're gonna start on Monday.

114
00:05:32.254 --> 00:05:34.500
And so you need to create
a user account for them, but

115
00:05:34.500 --> 00:05:37.380
you don't know what computer
they're gonna use, right?

116
00:05:37.380 --> 00:05:40.020
I don't know what computer they're gonna
be on but I need to create this account.

117
00:05:40.020 --> 00:05:44.060
Well, if I had a central database I can
just go and create it in the database.

118
00:05:44.060 --> 00:05:47.430
I don't have to go and
create it on a particular computer.

119
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:50.455
Now they can go to any computer and
log in and it's gonna work.

120
00:05:50.455 --> 00:05:53.170
What if I want to reset my password?

121
00:05:53.170 --> 00:05:55.130
Maybe I have a local accounts,

122
00:05:55.130 --> 00:05:57.780
in this room right now I
see three computers right?

123
00:05:57.780 --> 00:06:01.480
So I go and create a user account for
Don Pezet on computer one, computer two,

124
00:06:01.480 --> 00:06:02.900
computer three.

125
00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:03.720
And then one day I say,

126
00:06:03.720 --> 00:06:07.162
you know my password's kind of weak,
I wanna change my password.

127
00:06:07.162 --> 00:06:08.970
I've gotta go computer one, computer two,

128
00:06:08.970 --> 00:06:11.630
computer three and
I’ve gotta change in all three places.

129
00:06:11.630 --> 00:06:15.490
What if a thousand computers, I'd have to
go and chase it in a thousand places, and

130
00:06:15.490 --> 00:06:17.290
that's not fun at all.

131
00:06:17.290 --> 00:06:18.190
Well, I'll go back to that.

132
00:06:18.190 --> 00:06:21.130
And unless you're an hourly employee,
then it's great.

133
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:22.810
So for most of us we don't want that.

134
00:06:22.810 --> 00:06:26.640
If I had a central database, I just go and
change the password in one place.

135
00:06:26.640 --> 00:06:27.820
I change it in that database, and

136
00:06:27.820 --> 00:06:30.890
now it's changed everywhere,
that makes life a lot easier.

137
00:06:31.910 --> 00:06:33.700
From an administrative stand
point it's also great when

138
00:06:33.700 --> 00:06:35.330
you need to disable an account.

139
00:06:35.330 --> 00:06:37.620
Let's say you have a disgruntled employee,
right?

140
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:41.940
Somebody's angry and so they get fired,
they get escorted out of the building.

141
00:06:41.940 --> 00:06:44.310
Well, they could sneak right back in and
log in on a computer and

142
00:06:44.310 --> 00:06:45.320
start doing some damage.

143
00:06:45.320 --> 00:06:48.000
So I need to disable their
account as quickly as possible.

144
00:06:48.000 --> 00:06:50.650
If they've got an account
on 1,000 computers

145
00:06:50.650 --> 00:06:52.710
I can't do that very quickly, can I?

146
00:06:52.710 --> 00:06:54.110
But if this is a centralized database,

147
00:06:54.110 --> 00:06:57.100
I just go to the database,
take that user, disable them, right?

148
00:06:57.100 --> 00:06:59.700
And delete them, change their password,
whatever it is you wanna do.

149
00:06:59.700 --> 00:07:01.850
Any of those will lock that person out and

150
00:07:01.850 --> 00:07:04.570
now they can't get into the system again,
right?

151
00:07:04.570 --> 00:07:08.730
So those are all advantages of
having a centralized directory and

152
00:07:08.730 --> 00:07:09.890
the Apple's Open Directory does that.

153
00:07:10.890 --> 00:07:13.270
The Open Directory is part
of the server app, so

154
00:07:13.270 --> 00:07:14.500
getting it installed is super easy.

155
00:07:14.500 --> 00:07:16.780
You just install the server app,
and you've got it.

156
00:07:16.780 --> 00:07:20.120
So if we take a look at my server here,
I haven't configured it on this one,

157
00:07:20.120 --> 00:07:21.210
I just fired it up.

158
00:07:21.210 --> 00:07:26.130
Here's my server app and Open Directory
is actually part of the Advanced servers.

159
00:07:26.130 --> 00:07:29.350
So, it's hidden by default,
you'll have to expand that out.

160
00:07:29.350 --> 00:07:33.200
And then you'll see Open Directory
right there on the list, right?

161
00:07:33.200 --> 00:07:38.980
Now, the Open Directory is turned
off by default and with a lot

162
00:07:38.980 --> 00:07:44.500
of the servers here you can normally kind
of configure them and then turn them on.

163
00:07:44.500 --> 00:07:45.810
Open Directory is a little bit different.

164
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:48.910
It makes you turn on first and
then configure it.

165
00:07:48.910 --> 00:07:51.550
So it's a little bit backwards compared
to some of the other services.

166
00:07:51.550 --> 00:07:55.199
So, when you go to set this up your first
step is really just to hit that On button,

167
00:07:55.199 --> 00:07:57.202
even before you've done a configuration.

168
00:07:57.202 --> 00:07:58.329
And the reason is,

169
00:07:58.329 --> 00:08:02.994
it's going to then pop up the wizard
that walks us through the configuration.

170
00:08:02.994 --> 00:08:06.838
Open Directory is one of the more
difficult ones to get set up because it's

171
00:08:06.838 --> 00:08:09.090
just a lot of questions that it asks.

172
00:08:09.090 --> 00:08:11.810
Most of the other services,
you can kinda stumble through them,

173
00:08:11.810 --> 00:08:13.200
like I wanna configure mail.

174
00:08:13.200 --> 00:08:17.740
So I'll just turn it on and fumble through
the options until we get it right.

175
00:08:17.740 --> 00:08:19.170
And it's not that hard.

176
00:08:19.170 --> 00:08:23.810
Open Directory, you can make mistakes
early on that can't be fixed,

177
00:08:23.810 --> 00:08:26.230
that break the directory,
that break the functionality.

178
00:08:26.230 --> 00:08:29.750
So we need to make sure we understand each
decision along the way that we're making.

179
00:08:29.750 --> 00:08:31.130
And so it is a little bit different.

180
00:08:31.130 --> 00:08:33.690
And that's why I wanted to spend some
time in this episode covering it,

181
00:08:33.690 --> 00:08:36.580
even though it's not on
the exam objectives, all right.

182
00:08:36.580 --> 00:08:38.822
The first thing your gonna
see when you launch this is,

183
00:08:38.822 --> 00:08:40.585
it's gonna ask what you're trying to do.

184
00:08:40.585 --> 00:08:44.360
Are you trying to create
a new Open Directory domain?

185
00:08:44.360 --> 00:08:45.710
That's usually what we want.

186
00:08:45.710 --> 00:08:49.635
A domain, think of domain as like that
that database, the database of users.

187
00:08:49.635 --> 00:08:51.150
So we have a domain,

188
00:08:51.150 --> 00:08:55.840
it's a name that identifies the users
that are grouped together, right.

189
00:08:55.840 --> 00:08:57.000
When I create a new database,

190
00:08:57.000 --> 00:09:01.200
I'm creating a new Open Directory
domain to gather these users together.

191
00:09:01.200 --> 00:09:04.836
I could join an existing
Open Directory domain.

192
00:09:04.836 --> 00:09:08.491
Which means I've already got Open
Directory configured somewhere else, and

193
00:09:08.491 --> 00:09:09.330
I want a replica.

194
00:09:10.590 --> 00:09:13.290
When you configure your first
Open Directory server it's called

195
00:09:13.290 --> 00:09:14.260
a master, right?

196
00:09:14.260 --> 00:09:17.140
It's the one that's in
charge of that database.

197
00:09:17.140 --> 00:09:19.670
Well, what happens if your master fails?

198
00:09:19.670 --> 00:09:23.656
If the master fails and all of my
user accounts were on that master,

199
00:09:23.656 --> 00:09:27.410
I can't log in to my Macs anymore, right?

200
00:09:27.410 --> 00:09:31.680
I might have 1,000 Macs on my network,
and now I can't log in to any of them.

201
00:09:31.680 --> 00:09:33.850
That's not where we wanna be, right?

202
00:09:33.850 --> 00:09:38.330
So it is a rare day that you deploy
just one Open Directory server.

203
00:09:38.330 --> 00:09:40.820
I mean, you gotta be really
confident in your network, and

204
00:09:40.820 --> 00:09:44.090
really confident in your career
[LAUGH] to just have one of these.

205
00:09:44.090 --> 00:09:45.090
You're going to want more.

206
00:09:45.090 --> 00:09:49.010
>> Now Don, the replica, is that a
read-only copy or is that a writable copy

207
00:09:49.010 --> 00:09:53.730
of that centralized database that's so
important that we maintain redundancy?

208
00:09:53.730 --> 00:09:57.279
>> So it is just readable, right,
so when you, I shouldn't say right.

209
00:09:57.279 --> 00:10:03.100
[LAUGH] So when you have a database,
you need consistent writes to a database.

210
00:10:03.100 --> 00:10:08.120
What if I go to two different computers
and, or maybe Wes knows my password.

211
00:10:08.120 --> 00:10:10.419
And he sits down on one computer and
he goes to change my password and

212
00:10:10.419 --> 00:10:12.608
I sit down on another computer and
I try and change my password.

213
00:10:12.608 --> 00:10:14.390
We try and change it at the same time.

214
00:10:14.390 --> 00:10:17.000
Well, if we're writing to
the same database that's fine,

215
00:10:17.000 --> 00:10:18.900
it's just the last one wins.

216
00:10:18.900 --> 00:10:20.930
But if we're writing to
different databases,

217
00:10:20.930 --> 00:10:22.950
now there's a conflict,
there's a challenge.

218
00:10:22.950 --> 00:10:25.340
So your master is the one that's
gonna be doing all the work.

219
00:10:25.340 --> 00:10:27.820
Your replicas are there for redundancy.

220
00:10:27.820 --> 00:10:31.020
If the master fails,
a replica can take over.

221
00:10:31.020 --> 00:10:33.200
So you're not allowed to write
to the replica by default but

222
00:10:33.200 --> 00:10:34.480
you can read from it.

223
00:10:34.480 --> 00:10:35.680
And that's exactly gonna happen.

224
00:10:35.680 --> 00:10:38.241
When your master fails,
all of your clients,

225
00:10:38.241 --> 00:10:41.865
you'll still be able to log in cuz

it's comparing hashes.

451
00:21:43.190 --> 00:21:46.030
So if somebody intercepts this traffic on
the network, they don't get your password.

452
00:21:46.030 --> 00:21:47.820
They just get a hash which is useless.

453
00:21:47.820 --> 00:21:51.020
>> Don, from the client standpoint
on this, this binding of it to

454
00:21:51.020 --> 00:21:54.830
the Open Directory almost seems like
a trust relationship that it's forming.

455
00:21:54.830 --> 00:21:59.320
It's saying hey, if that username, if that
account is up on that server and you trust

456
00:21:59.320 --> 00:22:02.720
him when you login their credentials here,
I'll go ahead and trust them as well.

457
00:22:02.720 --> 00:22:06.490
>> That is a great description of it
because that's exactly what's happening.

458
00:22:06.490 --> 00:22:08.920
We don't know all the user
accounts on the directory server.

459
00:22:08.920 --> 00:22:11.855
And there could be a brand new user
account that was created two minutes ago.

460
00:22:11.855 --> 00:22:15.160
Your work station doesn't know about it
but when that person logs in the first

461
00:22:15.160 --> 00:22:18.560
time we'll trust it because it
exists on the directory server.

462
00:22:18.560 --> 00:22:22.140
So now I'm logged in and
I'm logged in as Wes.

463
00:22:22.140 --> 00:22:27.940
And if he goes into System Preferences and
goes into Users and Groups.

464
00:22:27.940 --> 00:22:31.290
When we jump in here, look what it did?

465
00:22:31.290 --> 00:22:33.790
Wes Bryan, Network account.

466
00:22:33.790 --> 00:22:34.290
Right?

467
00:22:34.290 --> 00:22:37.268
Not a local account like these guys
down here but a network account.

468
00:22:37.268 --> 00:22:40.404
He's coming from the directory but
now he's able to login and work and

469
00:22:40.404 --> 00:22:41.470
use this system.

470
00:22:41.470 --> 00:22:41.990
Right?

471
00:22:41.990 --> 00:22:46.030
This works station is now bound
to the Open Directory and

472
00:22:46.030 --> 00:22:48.120
people can login using
the Network account.

473
00:22:48.120 --> 00:22:52.670
And if Wes were to change his password by
using Change Password button it's actually

474
00:22:52.670 --> 00:22:57.110
gonna change it on the server,
not changing it here on the client.

475
00:22:57.110 --> 00:23:00.340
And that way if he goes to any of
the other computers in the network,

476
00:23:00.340 --> 00:23:02.460
his new password already takes effect.

477
00:23:02.460 --> 00:23:06.760
And as an administrator if I wanna kill
off his account I can come right here

478
00:23:06.760 --> 00:23:11.330
in to the Users list and I can disable
his account and cut his access off or

479
00:23:11.330 --> 00:23:14.180
reset his password or
delete the user, right?

480
00:23:14.180 --> 00:23:17.580
And once that happens,
he's now lost access to the network and

481
00:23:17.580 --> 00:23:18.940
he's not been able to get in.

482
00:23:18.940 --> 00:23:20.470
So we've got that functionality.

483
00:23:20.470 --> 00:23:22.540
We have centralized management or
our User Accounts,

484
00:23:22.540 --> 00:23:25.170
and that's kind of
the critical piece here.

485
00:23:25.170 --> 00:23:28.570
The other thing is,
let's say you've got a help desk.

486
00:23:28.570 --> 00:23:31.750
And your help desk needs to be able to
login to people's computers to help them.

487
00:23:31.750 --> 00:23:35.070
Well, normally we have to create a help
desk account on everybody's machine.

488
00:23:35.070 --> 00:23:37.060
Here I can have a help desk
account that's centralized,

489
00:23:37.060 --> 00:23:39.040
that they can then reach out and
login to these systems.

490
00:23:39.040 --> 00:23:40.980
So, it makes administration
a lot easier and

491
00:23:40.980 --> 00:23:43.970
that also doubles back to the reason
why I wanted to film this episode.

492
00:23:43.970 --> 00:23:46.690
In the next episode we're gonna
do the Profile Manager, and

493
00:23:46.690 --> 00:23:50.540
the Profile Manager is gonna push out
configuration settings to the clients.

494
00:23:50.540 --> 00:23:53.020
And it needs some kind of
credentials to do that.

495
00:23:53.020 --> 00:23:56.790
And when we bind to a directory server
like this, it makes that possible,

496
00:23:56.790 --> 00:23:57.810
makes that easy.

497
00:23:57.810 --> 00:24:01.940
You actually can use the profile
manager without an Open Directory, but

498
00:24:01.940 --> 00:24:04.950
it's not designed to work that way and
it makes things a lot more difficult.

499
00:24:04.950 --> 00:24:09.020
So, Apple's official recommendation is,
if you're gonna use Profile Manager,

500
00:24:09.020 --> 00:24:11.260
you really do need to have
an Open Directory in place.

501
00:24:11.260 --> 00:24:12.360
>> Very good.
In this episode,

502
00:24:12.360 --> 00:24:15.740
we've been looking at Open Directory and
the benefits of the centralized

503
00:24:15.740 --> 00:24:18.110
administration that it can give you and
your network.

504
00:24:18.110 --> 00:24:20.090
Don, you have anything else for
us in this episode?

505
00:24:20.090 --> 00:24:20.950
>> That's about it on this one.

506
00:24:20.950 --> 00:24:22.310
I know it's a little bit
shorter of an episode but

507
00:24:22.310 --> 00:24:24.750
stay tuned because we're gonna
get into Profile Manager next and

508
00:24:24.750 --> 00:24:26.200
that's where we're gonna
leverage all of this.

509
00:24:26.200 --> 00:24:26.720
>> All right.

510
00:24:26.720 --> 00:24:29.070
Well, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

511
00:24:29.070 --> 00:24:30.550
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

512
00:24:30.550 --> 00:24:31.680
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

513
00:24:31.680 --> 00:24:33.617
>> And we'll see you next time.

514
00:24:33.617 --> 00:24:41.270
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at configuring and controlling setting to Apple devices through a powerful utility known as Profile Manager. They discuss the what is required to install and use the Profile Manager. They talk about the main components in Profile Manager like the Self-Service User Portal, Mobile Device Management (MDM) and the Web-based Administration Tool. They explore how the policies can be distributed through email, MDM or even user download.
episodes.title: Profile Manager
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.120 --> 00:00:15.335
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.335 --> 00:00:16.934
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.934 --> 00:00:21.491
in today's episode we're gonna be diving
in to the world of Mac and Mac management.

5
00:00:21.491 --> 00:00:25.440
So, here with Mac management basics
to help us out is Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:26.740
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:26.740 --> 00:00:27.764
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:27.764 --> 00:00:31.110
Fired up, jump into another exciting
episode, because in this episode, we're

9
00:00:31.110 --> 00:00:35.330
gonna take a look at the Profile Manager,
which is a insanely powerful piece of

10
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:39.040
software that is built into the Server
app inside of Mac OS, so it's a fun one.

11
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:40.530
There's a lot of a really cool stuff.

12
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:44.010
You'll see, this is one of those
technologies that you cover that, yeah,

13
00:00:44.010 --> 00:00:45.550
it's kinda hard to get it turned on and
set up.

14
00:00:45.550 --> 00:00:48.670
But once it's set up,
the world is your oyster.

15
00:00:48.670 --> 00:00:50.970
There are so
many options inside of this thing.

16
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:54.490
You can do so much stuff with it, that
it gets the gears moving in your head.

17
00:00:54.490 --> 00:00:56.320
You know like,
what all can I do with this?

18
00:00:56.320 --> 00:00:57.710
It's pretty amazing stuff.

19
00:00:57.710 --> 00:01:00.860
So, if you've never heard of the Profile
Manager, I guess let me back up.

20
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:04.100
I'm hyping it up here and
I haven't even told you what it is.

21
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:07.370
When we deploy a Mac,
it's got a lot of settings on it.

22
00:01:07.370 --> 00:01:10.330
Some of the settings are simple,
like what's your wallpaper.

23
00:01:10.330 --> 00:01:13.270
Some are more complex,
like what apps do you have, or

24
00:01:13.270 --> 00:01:16.550
what's your energy saving settings,
and so on.

25
00:01:16.550 --> 00:01:19.180
All of those are configuration
settings that are stored in preference

26
00:01:19.180 --> 00:01:20.520
files on your Mac.

27
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:24.100
And if I have one Mac, and I want to
get it set up the way that I want,

28
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:25.670
I just sit down and I do it,
and that's the end of it.

29
00:01:25.670 --> 00:01:26.880
It is that easy.

30
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:30.120
But if I have a thousand Macs and
I want them all set up

31
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:34.110
the particular way that I want,
it becomes a lot more difficult.

32
00:01:34.110 --> 00:01:37.080
And we talked about this back in
the NetInstall episodes, right?

33
00:01:37.080 --> 00:01:39.460
That I said, if I'm about to deploy
a thousand Macs in my network and

34
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:43.950
I want them all set the same way, well,
I can create an installation image.

35
00:01:43.950 --> 00:01:45.789
I can make a NetInstall image or

36
00:01:45.789 --> 00:01:49.907
a NetRestore image that has everything
set exactly the way I want it.

37
00:01:49.907 --> 00:01:53.660
And then I can roll it out to all
thousand computers, and I'm done, right?

38
00:01:53.660 --> 00:01:56.659
Well, I'm done that day.

39
00:01:56.659 --> 00:01:58.572
What about tomorrow or the next day?

40
00:01:58.572 --> 00:02:02.270
Well, I'm not buying a thousand
new computers every single day.

41
00:02:02.270 --> 00:02:06.430
But, I turn them over to my end users,
and the end users start doing, well,

42
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:08.461
the stuff that end users do, right?

43
00:02:08.461 --> 00:02:11.862
They start changing that wallpaper and
installing garbage apps, and doing all

44
00:02:11.862 --> 00:02:15.225
the crazy things that happens when you
put a computer into somebody's hands.

45
00:02:15.225 --> 00:02:18.160
And it starts to get away from
the way that we had it set up, right?

46
00:02:18.160 --> 00:02:21.400
Let's use power savings as an example.

47
00:02:21.400 --> 00:02:26.170
Let's say that my company is open
from 9 AM to 5 PM every day.

48
00:02:26.170 --> 00:02:30.230
And I know that a lot of people leave
their computers on at the end of the day,

49
00:02:30.230 --> 00:02:34.170
so when 5 PM rolls around and people
leave their computer on, they go home.

50
00:02:34.170 --> 00:02:36.230
And the computer's just sitting there,

51
00:02:36.230 --> 00:02:37.970
running up my electric
bill all night long.

52
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:39.950
So I want the computer to go to sleep.

53
00:02:39.950 --> 00:02:43.710
So, I set it, so that every computer,
if it sits there idle for

54
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:47.620
30 minutes, goes to sleep, and
we'll push those out into the field.

55
00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:50.490
Well, then my end users get a hold of it,
and throughout the day,

56
00:02:50.490 --> 00:02:53.050
they're like, I hate it when I come back
from lunch and the computer's asleep.

57
00:02:53.050 --> 00:02:55.840
I'm gonna turn that off,
and they turn it off.

58
00:02:55.840 --> 00:03:00.140
Well, it just ruined my perfect
vision of energy savings.

59
00:03:00.140 --> 00:03:03.990
Right?
So, I need a way to enforce those settings

60
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:06.120
after the image is out, right?

61
00:03:06.120 --> 00:03:08.400
After the computer's already
in somebody's hands.

62
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:10.300
I've already got it set the way I want it.

63
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:13.000
How do I keep it set the way that I want?

64
00:03:14.010 --> 00:03:16.440
And the answer is, the Profile Manager.

65
00:03:16.440 --> 00:03:18.510
The Profile Manager lets you do that.

66
00:03:18.510 --> 00:03:21.300
You can build a collection of settings.

67
00:03:21.300 --> 00:03:25.030
And not only can you push it out to
the clients, you can enforce it.

68
00:03:25.030 --> 00:03:29.620
You can force them to do things
a certain way, and they can't change it.

69
00:03:29.620 --> 00:03:32.960
Or, if through some miraculous
happenstance they do manage to change it,

70
00:03:32.960 --> 00:03:34.270
it just gets put right back,

71
00:03:34.270 --> 00:03:37.460
the next time the policy applies
which is usually every 24 hours.

72
00:03:37.460 --> 00:03:39.930
So, it's gonna happen pretty quickly.

73
00:03:39.930 --> 00:03:41.790
And now it gets put back
to the way that it was.

74
00:03:41.790 --> 00:03:44.690
So, that's what the Profile Manager
is designed for.

75
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:45.820
Now, some of this might sound familiar.

76
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:48.610
If you're an old school Mac person,
if you've been working with it for

77
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:52.220
a while, you might remember something
called a managed preference, right?

78
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:54.080
Managed preferences were the old system,
and

79
00:03:54.080 --> 00:03:56.390
Profile Manager replaced it
a couple of versions ago.

80
00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:58.540
So I doubt you'll see that on the exam,
but just in case some of

81
00:03:58.540 --> 00:04:01.630
you guys are going I thought this
was called Manage Preferences?

82
00:04:01.630 --> 00:04:02.810
Well you're right,
that's what it used to be.

83
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:05.370
And what Manage Preferences was,
it was a lot more manual.

84
00:04:05.370 --> 00:04:09.860
We're gonna see with the Profile Manager,
we can do this entirely over the network.

85
00:04:09.860 --> 00:04:12.540
And not just our network,
we can do it all over the world.

86
00:04:12.540 --> 00:04:15.820
You can have people with Macs on networks
that you've never even heard of.

87
00:04:15.820 --> 00:04:18.050
They can be at a hotel somewhere.

88
00:04:18.050 --> 00:04:21.250
And their system can connect
up to your Profile Manager and

89
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:23.930
have the settings apply to it,
just the way that you want.

90
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:27.448
So you can control machines
in the building with you, and

91
00:04:27.448 --> 00:04:30.170
you can control them
even after they leave.

92
00:04:30.170 --> 00:04:32.940
And that's when we start
getting into what's called MDM.

93
00:04:32.940 --> 00:04:34.980
Mobile Device Management.

94
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:37.290
Let's say, you've got a company laptop.

95
00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:41.050
And you're at airport and
somebody steals the laptop.

96
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:42.770
You just loss control of it.

97
00:04:42.770 --> 00:04:45.560
What about all your company
data that's on that laptop?

98
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:48.600
Well, with Profile Manager
we can remote wipe it.

99
00:04:48.600 --> 00:04:50.630
We can send a wipe command.

100
00:04:50.630 --> 00:04:52.910
And the next time that laptop
gets an Internet connection,

101
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:54.690
it will erase your data, right?

102
00:04:54.690 --> 00:04:58.090
So you can actually preserve and
protect your information by using this.

103
00:04:58.090 --> 00:04:59.590
It's really powerful stuff.

104
00:04:59.590 --> 00:05:00.380
It's a neat product.

105
00:05:00.380 --> 00:05:01.850
It's kinda why I get so excited.

106
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:06.090
I get fired up about this because I
know there's so much power in this.

107
00:05:06.090 --> 00:05:07.984
But just getting it turned on
is a little bit rough, and so

108
00:05:07.984 --> 00:05:09.968
we're gonna walk through that
right here in this episode.

109
00:05:09.968 --> 00:05:12.261
How do we get it turned on,
get it put in place, and

110
00:05:12.261 --> 00:05:14.570
then we'll start pushing
some settings with it.

111
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:19.100
>> Don, you showed us in
the caching software the notes.

112
00:05:19.100 --> 00:05:21.140
You guys sometimes don't see
the notes beforehand, and

113
00:05:21.140 --> 00:05:26.320
Don had almost no, barely anything for
notes on the caching server.

114
00:05:26.320 --> 00:05:28.885
This one here,
I've got five pages of notes.

115
00:05:28.885 --> 00:05:31.880
[LAUGH] So guys,
good information coming up.

116
00:05:31.880 --> 00:05:34.530
Don, there are some
prerequisites that we need.

117
00:05:34.530 --> 00:05:36.960
Right?
Some things that are required in order to

118
00:05:36.960 --> 00:05:38.586
set this profile manager up?

119
00:05:38.586 --> 00:05:40.640
>> Yeah, you know, Profile Manager,
it wasn't always around.

120
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:41.940
We used to have those managed preferences.

121
00:05:41.940 --> 00:05:44.845
And so,
it was really introduced in OS 10.7.

122
00:05:44.845 --> 00:05:47.344
So you have to really be running 10.7 and
higher.

123
00:05:47.344 --> 00:05:51.394
And some of the options that we're gonna
see as we set it up were introduced in

124
00:05:51.394 --> 00:05:53.820
10.9, just back in Mavericks.

125
00:05:53.820 --> 00:05:57.961
So, if you're running the newer Mac OSs,
if you're running Mavericks and higher,

126
00:05:57.961 --> 00:06:00.220
100% of what you see here works just fine.

127
00:06:01.420 --> 00:06:03.788
But if you're running
some of the older OSs,

128
00:06:03.788 --> 00:06:07.463
if you're running any of the Snow Leopards
or cat ones, any of those,

129
00:06:07.463 --> 00:06:10.164
well some of the features work,
some don't work.

130
00:06:10.164 --> 00:06:12.000
Prior to 10.7,
none of the features worked.

131
00:06:12.000 --> 00:06:13.608
So you really do need to have newer ones,
and

132
00:06:13.608 --> 00:06:15.990
Apple's starting to be a little
more strict about that.

133
00:06:15.990 --> 00:06:19.945
They're not going back and supporting
OSs back to the beginning of time.

134
00:06:19.945 --> 00:06:21.550
They're kinda keeping it
with their newer ones.

135
00:06:21.550 --> 00:06:25.280
You gotta stay up to date, which is why
we're filming these El Capitan episodes

136
00:06:25.280 --> 00:06:28.050
right now,
because we've got to stay up to date.

137
00:06:28.050 --> 00:06:30.690
All right, so
that's one set of requirements we've got.

138
00:06:30.690 --> 00:06:33.250
The other thing is you are gonna
need a server somewhere.

139
00:06:33.250 --> 00:06:36.360
Which is really just a Mac OS machine
that has the Server app installed.

140
00:06:36.360 --> 00:06:38.020
That's kind of the critical thing.

141
00:06:38.020 --> 00:06:41.760
You're also going to need an Apple ID,
right?

142
00:06:41.760 --> 00:06:44.610
You've gotta have an Apple ID, because
this one has to register with Apple.

143
00:06:44.610 --> 00:06:46.960
Remember how I said it works
anywhere in the world?

144
00:06:46.960 --> 00:06:48.790
Well, that means we
gotta check in somehow.

145
00:06:48.790 --> 00:06:50.650
And we check in through Apple's server.

146
00:06:50.650 --> 00:06:52.570
So you gotta have an Apple ID too,
all right?

147
00:06:52.570 --> 00:06:54.280
Now when we get this set up,

148
00:06:54.280 --> 00:06:56.770
the Profile Manager's actually
made up of three different pieces.

149
00:06:56.770 --> 00:07:01.250
There's the three chunks that we largely
don't have to deal with specifically.

150
00:07:01.250 --> 00:07:04.920
The key thing is, there's a web
page that we use to administer it.

151
00:07:04.920 --> 00:07:08.380
That's different than all of the other
servers that we set up in the Server app.

152
00:07:08.380 --> 00:07:11.010
All the other stuff we manage right
from inside of the Server app.

153
00:07:11.010 --> 00:07:13.790
With the Profile Manager we turn
it on in the Server app, but

154
00:07:13.790 --> 00:07:17.060
then we have a web portal we
actually go to to administer it.

155
00:07:17.060 --> 00:07:21.040
There's a separate web portal for your end
users, so that end users can login and

156
00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:22.240
manage their own device.

157
00:07:22.240 --> 00:07:26.100
If an end user loses a phone, they could
actually go to the Profile Manager

158

00:27:55.000 --> 00:27:57.180
And people can be in more than one group.

615
00:27:57.180 --> 00:28:01.610
I might have somebody who's a teacher, but
they're also administrative staff, and so

616
00:28:01.610 --> 00:28:03.080
I have them in two different groups and

617
00:28:03.080 --> 00:28:05.820
they'll get kinda
a combination of the settings.

618
00:28:05.820 --> 00:28:10.530
And then over here, we get our first kind
of highlight of what those settings are.

619
00:28:10.530 --> 00:28:12.280
You'll see that there's
a lot of stuff in here.

620
00:28:12.280 --> 00:28:13.880
Just basic restrictions.

621
00:28:13.880 --> 00:28:18.370
We've got apps and books,
activity and so on.

622
00:28:18.370 --> 00:28:21.530
Each one of these
are collections of Settings.

623
00:28:21.530 --> 00:28:27.300
When I go under Settings, I don't see
a whole lot, but I do see messages, right?

624
00:28:27.300 --> 00:28:31.520
I'm pushing a configuration for messages
cuz I had that option turned on in

625
00:28:31.520 --> 00:28:33.520
settings for
everyone back in the server app.

626
00:28:33.520 --> 00:28:36.440
If I turn that off, this wouldn't be here
and I actually wouldn't see anything.

627
00:28:36.440 --> 00:28:39.330
Okay, well,
you always see Enrollment Settings.

628
00:28:39.330 --> 00:28:42.140
Under apps, I see nothing, no apps.

629
00:28:42.140 --> 00:28:44.420
Under books, I see nothing, no books.

630
00:28:44.420 --> 00:28:46.730
I haven't configured any of that yet,
right?

631
00:28:46.730 --> 00:28:51.480
So, when you first fire this up,
most of what you see is empty.

632
00:28:51.480 --> 00:28:52.900
And then it's up to us to go and

633
00:28:52.900 --> 00:28:57.480
configure all of those settings
exactly the way that we want, so

634
00:28:57.480 --> 00:29:00.780
that we can start managing those services,
those settings, and those other features.

635
00:29:00.780 --> 00:29:03.590
So, if you go into an environment where
they've been running the profile manager

636
00:29:03.590 --> 00:29:08.270
a long time, you might come to one of
these screens and see tons of data on it,

637
00:29:08.270 --> 00:29:11.180
or you might just see two little boxes
like I'm seeing cuz it's brand new.

638
00:29:11.180 --> 00:29:13.860
All right, but in the next episode
what we're gonna do is run through and

639
00:29:13.860 --> 00:29:16.280
get these set up and you'll start
to see a ton of these options.

640
00:29:16.280 --> 00:29:18.337
In fact,
those really the next two steps we need.

641
00:29:18.337 --> 00:29:23.132
Step one, we need to create some profiles.

642
00:29:23.132 --> 00:29:27.153
And in step two, we need to apply
them to a client to see it in action.

643
00:29:27.153 --> 00:29:29.550
So, we're gonna see that, but
I know I don't have enough time for that.

644
00:29:29.550 --> 00:29:30.810
But let me just show you one more thing.

645
00:29:30.810 --> 00:29:33.560
I mentioned those groups, and
how we can get them created.

646
00:29:33.560 --> 00:29:35.490
There's two types of groups.

647
00:29:35.490 --> 00:29:39.490
There's groups for user accounts,
and there's groups for devices.

648
00:29:39.490 --> 00:29:41.910
For your user accounts,
you can actually go under users.

649
00:29:41.910 --> 00:29:44.760
And I can create profiles
that apply to a single user,

650
00:29:44.760 --> 00:29:46.590
if I wanna be really specific.

651
00:29:46.590 --> 00:29:50.750
But groups work better, and with the
groups, I can go back to my server app,

652
00:29:50.750 --> 00:29:54.020
I can go to groups and
I can create my groups right here.

653
00:29:54.020 --> 00:29:57.850
I just have to be careful, when you create
a group it's gotta be a network group.

654
00:29:57.850 --> 00:30:00.130
If I choose a local group
it's not gonna work.

655
00:30:00.130 --> 00:30:02.752
And so,
I'm gonna create a network group and

656
00:30:02.752 --> 00:30:05.657
maybe I'll create one called Teachers,
right?

657
00:30:05.657 --> 00:30:09.460
And, I'll say okay to that one.

658
00:30:09.460 --> 00:30:11.370
And then,
I'll create another one called Students.

659
00:30:15.570 --> 00:30:16.360
We'll say okay to that.

660
00:30:17.610 --> 00:30:19.940
All right, so now I've created
the students and the teachers.

661
00:30:19.940 --> 00:30:21.880
And I can put user accounts into those, so

662
00:30:21.880 --> 00:30:24.180
I know who's a teacher and
who's a student.

663
00:30:24.180 --> 00:30:27.870
And if I go back here to profile manager,
they already showed up.

664
00:30:27.870 --> 00:30:30.350
Sometimes they don't show up right away,
and that's why there's a refresh button,

665
00:30:30.350 --> 00:30:31.760
which is what I was just
about to point out,

666
00:30:31.760 --> 00:30:33.620
but I don't need it cuz
they show up right away.

667
00:30:33.620 --> 00:30:34.520
So, there we go.

668
00:30:34.520 --> 00:30:37.430
I've got students and teachers, right?

669
00:30:37.430 --> 00:30:40.160
But you can group your computers also.

670
00:30:40.160 --> 00:30:42.750
I might have laptops and desktops.

671
00:30:42.750 --> 00:30:46.720
Well, the server app doesn't
do computer objects.

672
00:30:46.720 --> 00:30:48.230
It doesn't give you a way to do that.

673
00:30:48.230 --> 00:30:50.660
So, that's why we have
device groups up here.

674
00:30:50.660 --> 00:30:52.920
So, you can start to create
devices in device groups.

675
00:30:52.920 --> 00:30:55.057
Now under devices,
I don't have any devices yet, so

676
00:30:55.057 --> 00:30:57.320
I just see the space to
the enrollment screen.

677
00:30:57.320 --> 00:31:00.379
But if I go to device groups,
I can start to create device groups.

678
00:31:00.379 --> 00:31:05.416
And so, I'm gonna add one here,
just called new device group,

679
00:31:05.416 --> 00:31:09.239
and once it gets created
I can change its name, so

680
00:31:09.239 --> 00:31:14.299
I'm gonna make this one laptops,
right, and I'll save that.

681
00:31:14.299 --> 00:31:20.984
And then, I can create another one and
I'll call this one Desktops, right?

682
00:31:20.984 --> 00:31:24.450
I might have one power management profile
that I wanna roll out for laptops.

683
00:31:24.450 --> 00:31:27.530
That's aggressive and a different power
management profile that I roll out to

684
00:31:27.530 --> 00:31:29.640
desktop that's not as aggressive, right?

685
00:31:29.640 --> 00:31:32.029
So, now I can do that cuz
I've created the groups.

686
00:31:32.029 --> 00:31:35.032
And as I enroll computers
in my profile manager,

687
00:31:35.032 --> 00:31:37.608
I'll be able to put them in these groups.

688
00:31:37.608 --> 00:31:40.482
So, I can say yeah, that's a laptop or
yeah that's a desktop by putting it in

689
00:31:40.482 --> 00:31:42.400
the right group and
starting to work with it there.

690
00:31:42.400 --> 00:31:46.046
So, that's another kinda basic framework
thing you've gotta do early on in setting

691
00:31:46.046 --> 00:31:47.118
up the profile manager.

692
00:31:47.118 --> 00:31:49.345
>> All right, looks like we're
out of time for this episode.

693
00:31:49.345 --> 00:31:51.145
Don, got anything else for us?

694
00:31:51.145 --> 00:31:54.933
>> I've got a ton Wes, but we definitely
can't cover it in this last minute,

695
00:31:54.933 --> 00:31:57.235
so stay tuned,
we're gonna have a part two.

696
00:31:57.235 --> 00:31:59.860
We gotta get a client join, we gotta
get some settings in place, we've seen

697
00:31:59.860 --> 00:32:02.377
the rate of the profile manager,
we haven't actually utilized it yet.

698
00:32:02.377 --> 00:32:03.151
And that's where the real fun is.

699
00:32:03.151 --> 00:32:04.205
So, stay tuned for that.

700
00:32:04.205 --> 00:32:08.376
>> Plenty more to come but signing off for
IT PRO.TV, I've been your host Wes Bryan.

701
00:32:08.376 --> 00:32:09.120
>> And I'm Don Peset.

702
00:32:09.120 --> 00:32:11.082
>> And we'll see you next time.

703
00:32:11.082 --> 00:32:18.750
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on the Profile Manager. They will demonstrate how to setup and configure users and groups. They walk through the process of creating a configuration profile as well as confirming that the profile is applied appropriately to the device. They also explain how to perform a removal of a device that is managed with a configuration profile.
episodes.title: Profile Manager Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.031 --> 00:00:10.031
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.079 --> 00:00:12.910
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITVPro.TV.

3
00:00:12.910 --> 00:00:16.041
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in this episode,

4
00:00:16.041 --> 00:00:19.972
we're gonna be moving along
in our Mac Management basics.

5
00:00:19.972 --> 00:00:23.728
And we're coming at you with a part two,
yeah, we talked a lot in the first one.

6
00:00:23.728 --> 00:00:25.986
But we still got plenty
of more good information.

7
00:00:25.986 --> 00:00:30.829
We have a man that I'm still convinced
that has binary and not DNA, Mr.

8
00:00:30.829 --> 00:00:31.646
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:31.646 --> 00:00:33.922
>> [LAUGH] Wes, thanks for
having me back on the show.

10
00:00:33.922 --> 00:00:37.684
And yeah, like I said, we're continuing
off of where we left on profile managers.

11
00:00:37.684 --> 00:00:42.166
So if you watched our last episode,
I showed you guys how to set up a profile

12
00:00:42.166 --> 00:00:45.222
manager on a server, and
to get it up and running.

13
00:00:45.222 --> 00:00:48.151
And then we didn't actually
use the darn thing, right?

14
00:00:48.151 --> 00:00:49.581
We spent the whole episode
just getting fired up.

15
00:00:49.581 --> 00:00:52.456
So in this episode,
we're going to actually use it.

16
00:00:52.456 --> 00:00:54.019
We're gonna take it and
kind of put it to some use.

17
00:00:54.019 --> 00:00:57.980
So basically there's two main tasks that
we didn't get to in the last episode.

18
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:01.855
The first is just creating profiles,
I need to create some collections

19
00:01:01.855 --> 00:01:04.650
of settings that I can
push out to my clients.

20
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:07.390
And then the second thing is,
well pushing that to the clients,

21
00:01:07.390 --> 00:01:09.180
actually using those profiles and
getting them in place.

22
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:11.940
So we're gonna take a look at both
of those right here in this episode,

23
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:13.790
and well we'll just get started.

24
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:17.536
So in the last episode, in case you
missed it, I created a couple of groups.

25
00:01:17.536 --> 00:01:20.344
I created a group called laptops and
a group called desktops, so

26
00:01:20.344 --> 00:01:23.450
that I could create profiles and
push them out based on those.

27
00:01:23.450 --> 00:01:26.840
And I created a group called students and
a group called teachers,

28
00:01:26.840 --> 00:01:30.730
because I might have really,
really tight restrictions on students.

29
00:01:30.730 --> 00:01:34.130
And less restrictions on teachers so
they can go in and modify things.

30
00:01:34.130 --> 00:01:37.739
So we created those groups and
those are gonna serve as the framework for

31
00:01:37.739 --> 00:01:41.063
our profiles, but we didn't
actually create profiles on them.

32
00:01:41.063 --> 00:01:43.116
And there's one profile
that was already created.

33
00:01:43.116 --> 00:01:47.379
We did see that in the last episode,
which is the settings for everyone, right?

34
00:01:47.379 --> 00:01:50.979
Settings for everyone, that's where we
have settings that apply to everybody

35
00:01:50.979 --> 00:01:52.872
regardless of what profile they're in.

36
00:01:52.872 --> 00:01:55.070
It's kind of like a default profile.

37
00:01:55.070 --> 00:01:57.300
So when we decide to implement
the profile manager,

38
00:01:57.300 --> 00:02:01.210
first thing we need to do is think about
where we want our settings to apply.

39
00:02:01.210 --> 00:02:03.570
If I have settings I want
to apply to everybody,

40
00:02:03.570 --> 00:02:06.210
I should put them in the settings for
everyone profile.

41
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:08.513
But if I just have them for
a particular group of people,

42
00:02:08.513 --> 00:02:10.184
I need to create a group to support that.

43
00:02:10.184 --> 00:02:13.380
So we've kind of already done that and
we're ready to dive in.

44
00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:16.002
One thing I do wanna tweak though,
I'm gonna go on my server.

45
00:02:16.002 --> 00:02:17.807
And I know I highlighted
this in the last episode.

46
00:02:17.807 --> 00:02:22.117
But when we have services like Messages,
configured or whatever.

47
00:02:22.117 --> 00:02:26.325
The Profile Manager can automatically push
their settings out to our clients, and

48
00:02:26.325 --> 00:02:27.479
I left that turned on.

49
00:02:27.479 --> 00:02:30.648
So here we've got this default
configuration profile settings for

50
00:02:30.648 --> 00:02:31.860
everyone.

51
00:02:31.860 --> 00:02:34.720
And in the configuration for it,
I'm including a configuration for

52
00:02:34.720 --> 00:02:35.760
those services.

53
00:02:35.760 --> 00:02:38.360
I'm just gonna uncheck that so
that I don't include it.

54
00:02:38.360 --> 00:02:40.380
I can always change my mind later and
put them back.

55
00:02:40.380 --> 00:02:43.150
But for right now, I wanna make sure
that the only settings in the profile

56
00:02:43.150 --> 00:02:45.949
are ones that I put there myself,
not ones that are automatically made.

57
00:02:47.150 --> 00:02:50.550
All right, once that's done, I can jump
into my profile manager and get to work.

58
00:02:50.550 --> 00:02:54.940
So to get into the Profile Manager I just
need to go, well into Safari, right?

59
00:02:54.940 --> 00:02:58.050
You can browse to your server
name slash profile manager.

60
00:02:58.050 --> 00:03:02.254
Or since I'm already in the server app I
can just use this short cut right here,

61
00:03:02.254 --> 00:03:04.368
to open the Profile Manager in Safari.

62
00:03:04.368 --> 00:03:08.144
All right, now once I'm in there, what I'm
gonna see are the different groups, and

63
00:03:08.144 --> 00:03:10.310
settings, and
things that I've already made.

64
00:03:10.310 --> 00:03:14.390
So here we can see the everyone group,
that's the settings for

65
00:03:14.390 --> 00:03:15.370
everyone I was talking about.

66
00:03:15.370 --> 00:03:17.639
And then there's Students,
there's Teachers.

67
00:03:17.639 --> 00:03:20.506
If I go under my Device Groups,
I'll see Laptops and Desktops.

68
00:03:20.506 --> 00:03:23.240
Those are all the ones we
made in the last episode.

69
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:26.380
Well if I have a setting I
want to apply to everyone,

70
00:03:26.380 --> 00:03:30.050
then I need to go right here to this
Everyone group and put it there.

71
00:03:30.050 --> 00:03:33.830
Usually there's not a whole lot we want
to apply to everyone in our company.

72
00:03:33.830 --> 00:03:35.936
But a great example is a password policy,
right?

73
00:03:35.936 --> 00:03:40.935
A lot of companies have a minimum password
strength policy or a password rotation.

74
00:03:40.935 --> 00:03:42.308
So let's say, 90 days,

75
00:03:42.308 --> 00:03:46.570
I wanna make sure that all of my employees
change their password every 90 days.

76
00:03:46.570 --> 00:03:49.560
Well if you have a local
MAC account on a MAC,

77
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:51.640
how often does it make
you change password?

78
00:03:52.690 --> 00:03:54.910
Never, your password lasts forever.

79
00:03:54.910 --> 00:03:57.499
If you have an open directory account, how
often do you have to change your password?

80
00:03:58.650 --> 00:04:00.290
Never, it doesn't make you do it.

81
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:04.350
So the default configurations on a Mac are
that you could have a password forever.

82
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:07.143
But I can enforce a password expiration
right here, and I'm gonna do that.

83
00:04:07.143 --> 00:04:11.530
I'm gonna go under Everyone, and then
over here I start to see the Settings.

84
00:04:11.530 --> 00:04:14.920
And we're gonna see a lot of different
settings that pertain to these profiles,

85
00:04:14.920 --> 00:04:17.380
most of which we aren't really
going to even mess with.

86
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:19.511
Some of them you'll see
are pretty important,

87
00:04:19.511 --> 00:04:21.647
like Allow configuration
profile downloads.

88
00:04:21.647 --> 00:04:24.590
[LAUGH] I kinda need them to be
able to download it to install it.

89
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:27.560
Otherwise, I'm gonna have to put the
profile on a USB key and take it over and

90
00:04:27.560 --> 00:04:28.870
install it, which is a little bit of work.

91
00:04:29.880 --> 00:04:31.854
We've got device enrollment and
unenrollment,

92
00:04:31.854 --> 00:04:35.194
whether I wanna allow people to join into
this or not, and typically, we want that.

93
00:04:35.194 --> 00:04:39.380
Allow device lock, allow passcodes
to be cleared, allow device wipe.

94
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:41.110
Do I want to enable that functionality?

95
00:04:41.110 --> 00:04:44.750
You don't have to, but honestly,
it's a great functionality.

96
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:45.658
Why would you want to turn that off?

97
00:04:45.658 --> 00:04:49.701
Well you might not want a student
to figure out a Teacher's password.

98
00:04:49.701 --> 00:04:52.221
And then remote wipe their machine,
because they're being funny, right?

99
00:04:52.221 --> 00:04:56.655
You could potentially do that, so that's
why you wanna turn those things off.

100
00:04:56.655 --> 00:05:02.766
When you go into the Settings tab,
this is where we see all of the settings,

101
00:05:02.766 --> 00:05:05.679
and I don't see a lot here, right?

102
00:05:05.679 --> 00:05:09.830
I see allow activation lock
command after an MDM enrollment.

103
00:05:09.830 --> 00:05:12.860
In other words,
once they sign it up into MDM,

104
00:05:12.860 --> 00:05:16.890
do I want to allow them to
be able to lock the machine?

105
00:05:16.890 --> 00:05:18.610
As far as activating it to work, right?

106
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:20.400
So can I block the machine off and

107
00:05:20.400 --> 00:05:23.370
not allow it to be activated
on anybody else's system?

108
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:24.954
Well, if I'm not
supporting mobile devices,

109
00:05:24.954 --> 00:05:26.666
that doesn't really mean anything to me,
right?

110
00:05:26.666 --> 00:05:29.700
If I'm just supporting laptops and
desktops, I don't care about that.

111
00:05:29.700 --> 00:05:31.315
But for mobile phones, that really helps.

112
00:05:31.315 --> 00:05:33.884
Cuz when people steal a phone,
a lot of times what they do,

113
00:05:33.884 --> 00:05:35.995
is they just erase the phone and
sell it on eBay.

114
00:05:35.995 --> 00:05:39.142
Well if I do an activation lock on it,
if they erase the phone,

115
00:05:39.142 --> 00:05:42.664
they won't be able to activate it,
which means they can't sell it.

116
00:05:42.664 --> 00:05:45.983
So you basically kind of killed off
the ability to sell that phone,

117
00:05:45.983 --> 00:05:47.119
which is a good thing.

118
00:05:47.119 --> 00:05:49.640
But under general settings here,
I've got basically nothing.

119
00:05:49.640 --> 00:05:53.970
It just says general and that's it, and
there's no real setting in this profile.

120
00:05:53.970 --> 00:05:55.870
Even the activation lock is not turned on,
so

121
00:05:55.870 --> 00:05:58.660
this profile is effectively
empty by default.

122
00:05:58.660 --> 00:06:00.280
I need to add settings.

123
00:06:00.280 --> 00:06:02.750
So I'm gonna go under General,
and I'll hit Edit.

124
00:06:02.750 --> 00:06:06.870
And now, we get our first glance at
what a Configuration Profile looks like.

125
00:06:06.870 --> 00:06:09.543
The Configurations Profiles,
they're broken up into three sections.

126
00:06:09.543 --> 00:06:13.417
So on the left side here, I'm gonna see
all the different things I can configure,

127
00:06:13.417 --> 00:06:17.080
General, Passcode, Mail, Exchange,
LDAP, Contacts, and so on.

128
00:06:17.080 --> 00:06:20.604
It's actually a very long list, okay?

129
00:06:20.604 --> 00:06:25.250
Now when you look at it you might notice
