00:28:04.738 --> 00:28:07.731
And so by doing this, by preseeding.

587
00:28:07.731 --> 00:28:11.540
They call it seeding,
S-E-E-D, seeding the device.

588
00:28:11.540 --> 00:28:14.960
We put it in here, it's early provisioned,
and it's just ready to rock.

589
00:28:14.960 --> 00:28:16.720
So kind of a neat function there.

590
00:28:16.720 --> 00:28:20.563
>> Great, in this episode, we've been
looking at our Profile Manager, and

591
00:28:20.563 --> 00:28:22.761
a lot of good information in this episode.

592
00:28:22.761 --> 00:28:24.780
Don, you have anything else for
us on this one?

593
00:28:24.780 --> 00:28:27.500
>> The only other thing is,
if you're not gonna have a device anymore,

594
00:28:27.500 --> 00:28:31.130
if you get rid of a device, you can
remove them from the Profile Manager.

595
00:28:31.130 --> 00:28:34.399
When you remove them, you can just go in.

596
00:28:34.399 --> 00:28:36.229
Here, let me just show you real quick.

597
00:28:36.229 --> 00:28:38.827
So let's say that we don't
have Don's Mac anymore.

598
00:28:38.827 --> 00:28:40.336
So you can go into these devices and

599
00:28:40.336 --> 00:28:44.040
you can just hit the little minus button
down here at the bottom to remove it.

600
00:28:44.040 --> 00:28:46.590
Now when you remove it,
it's got two choices.

601
00:28:46.590 --> 00:28:50.100
One to revert it to a placeholder, which
means we keep all the policy settings, but

602
00:28:50.100 --> 00:28:52.190
the device is now no
longer being spoken to.

603
00:28:52.190 --> 00:28:55.690
Or we can Unenroll where we
completely disconnect the device.

604
00:28:55.690 --> 00:28:58.645
And so that's what I'm gonna choose there,
and we'll unenroll it and

605
00:28:58.645 --> 00:28:59.884
it's gonna come out, okay?

606
00:28:59.884 --> 00:29:03.456
Now when that happens,
what happens to the device?

607
00:29:03.456 --> 00:29:04.930
Well it's not managed anymore.

608
00:29:04.930 --> 00:29:08.320
So it's got all these settings on it,
but now the user can over ride them.

609
00:29:08.320 --> 00:29:11.282
They can go in and change things,
they can go in and manipulate that.

610
00:29:11.282 --> 00:29:14.695
So that's unenrolling or
getting the device kind of chucked out.

611
00:29:14.695 --> 00:29:18.386
And you'll see that mine's got this
little kinda dashed circle thing.

612
00:29:18.386 --> 00:29:21.713
It'll stay like that for a little while,
cuz we're talking to the other device.

613
00:29:21.713 --> 00:29:25.079
And it's only once we get full
confirmation that it actually comes out of

614
00:29:25.079 --> 00:29:27.957
there, and it can take a little
bit of time for that to happen.

615
00:29:27.957 --> 00:29:30.985
>> Great information Don here,
but I gotta go columbo on you.

616
00:29:30.985 --> 00:29:33.914
Because just one more thing you
did mention that lock screen,

617
00:29:33.914 --> 00:29:35.786
are we gonna get a chance to see that?

618
00:29:35.786 --> 00:29:39.452
>> Yeah, I didn't show it cuz the machine
has to, it reboots and we saw that and

619
00:29:39.452 --> 00:29:40.500
I kinda gave up on it.

620
00:29:40.500 --> 00:29:43.985
But after it reboots it boots up into kind
of a almost like the recovery console in

621
00:29:43.985 --> 00:29:46.757
a way, it's a special console
that has that lock screen in it.

622
00:29:46.757 --> 00:29:48.990
Let me just flip over to it, there we go.

623
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:52.383
So if you had that device
that was locked out, right?

624
00:29:52.383 --> 00:29:56.318
That it had been remotely locked, you'd
turn it on and this is all you'd get.

625
00:29:56.318 --> 00:29:58.949
You see there's not a whole lot
of options to be found here.

626
00:29:58.949 --> 00:30:04.884
You've got Sleep, Restart, Shut Down,
and then your six digit pin code.

627
00:30:04.884 --> 00:30:08.138
So once we recover this laptop,
then we can punch in the code.

628
00:30:08.138 --> 00:30:09.310
Without that code, you can't use it.

629
00:30:09.310 --> 00:30:13.400
Now, a quick word of caution on that one,
if you're not using File Vault,

630
00:30:13.400 --> 00:30:16.120
people can still boot in target mode and
get at your data.

631
00:30:16.120 --> 00:30:18.899
So if you're using File Vault,
your drive's encrypted and

632
00:30:18.899 --> 00:30:19.940
now it really is safe.

633
00:30:19.940 --> 00:30:23.211
You don't have to worry about
anybody getting in there,

634
00:30:23.211 --> 00:30:25.606
unless they have your super secret code.

635
00:30:25.606 --> 00:30:27.622
And you probably don't wanna
use the one that I used.

636
00:30:27.622 --> 00:30:30.759
But if they have the code, then they can
unlock it, and it's gonna boot up and

637
00:30:30.759 --> 00:30:31.594
you'll be back in.

638
00:30:31.594 --> 00:30:35.084
So that's what that locked screen looks
like, and you can remote wipe anywhere

639
00:30:35.084 --> 00:30:38.436
that machine has a network connection,
you'll see it and lock the screen.

640
00:30:38.436 --> 00:30:39.094
>> That's awesome.

641
00:30:39.094 --> 00:30:42.234
Well, I'm gonna have to go and
change my passcode myself now.

642
00:30:42.234 --> 00:30:43.805
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're gonna go ahead and

643
00:30:43.805 --> 00:30:45.027
sign off here at ITPro.TV.

644
00:30:45.027 --> 00:30:46.546
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

645
00:30:46.546 --> 00:30:47.303
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

646
00:30:47.303 --> 00:30:49.210
>> And we'll see you next time.

647
00:30:49.210 --> 00:30:55.880
[MUSIC]

topics.title: Managing OS X Devices with Profile Manager

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at how to manage updates for not single machine but for hundreds or thousands of client machines through Apple's Software Update. They discuss Apple's recommended three phase best practice to deploying updates to clients. They demonstrate how to set up the Software Update server as well as configuring the client to recieve updates.
episodes.title: Managing Updates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.145 --> 00:00:10.145
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.414 --> 00:00:15.337
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.337 --> 00:00:16.346
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.346 --> 00:00:20.120
And in today's episode we're gonna be
moving through our Mac Management Basics.

5
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:23.540
And we got our in house Mac expert,
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:23.540 --> 00:00:24.608
Don, how you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:24.608 --> 00:00:25.595
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:25.595 --> 00:00:28.331
Ready to jump right back into
the world of Mac Manager Basics, and

9
00:00:28.331 --> 00:00:31.717
in this episode we're gonna take a look
at something that's pretty important,

10
00:00:31.717 --> 00:00:33.280
it's the software update service.

11
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:37.340
It's a part of the server app in OS10 and
it's been around a while,

12
00:00:37.340 --> 00:00:41.290
but it's right here in El Capitan, too,
and it is extremely important, more so

13
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:42.590
today than even in the past.

14
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:46.539
Because we are seeing a lot of security
updates getting pushed out and

15
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:54.320
things happen, things happen where hackers
find a vulnerability inside of Mac OS and

16
00:00:54.320 --> 00:00:57.600
they start to exploit it, and
Apple recognizes that pretty quick and

17
00:00:57.600 --> 00:01:01.310
as soon as they spot something like that,
they push out an update.

18
00:01:01.310 --> 00:01:04.540
Well, if you've got one or five Macs,

19
00:01:04.540 --> 00:01:08.690
you can just go and manually update them,
but it is up to you to go and update them.

20
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:13.220
If you have 1,000 Macs, how do you
know they're all getting updated?

21
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:17.620
Well the software update service lets us
control that and there's times when we

22
00:01:17.620 --> 00:01:21.140
wanna get updates out as fast as possible
and there's other times where we

23
00:01:21.140 --> 00:01:24.590
might wanna hold off and say,
you know what, my guys aren't ready for

24
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:28.490
this particular update just yet,
let's hold off on that for a little while.

25
00:01:28.490 --> 00:01:33.900
And so the software update service gives
us that ability to control the updates and

26
00:01:33.900 --> 00:01:35.550
put the ball in our court.

27
00:01:35.550 --> 00:01:37.960
Let us control it, let us determine
when the updates go out and

28
00:01:37.960 --> 00:01:42.090
ensure that they're getting out there and
keep our systems up to date.

29
00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:45.869
All right, so let's talk a little bit
about, well I definitely wanna talk about

30
00:01:45.869 --> 00:01:48.940
the software update service,
that's why I said all that stuff.

31
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:50.935
But before we jump in and implement it,

32
00:01:50.935 --> 00:01:53.600
I wanna talk about some of
Apple's best practices.

33
00:01:55.090 --> 00:01:58.140
There's some updates,
like critical security updates,

34
00:01:58.140 --> 00:02:00.420
that you need to get out
as fast as possible.

35
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:04.270
So, for example, just last week there
was a new ransomware that was out there,

36
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:06.280
it was called KeRanger and

37
00:02:06.280 --> 00:02:09.490
it would encrypt your data on
a Mac if you got infected with it.

38
00:02:09.490 --> 00:02:14.560
Apple had an update put out within hours
of detection of this ransomware, and

39
00:02:14.560 --> 00:02:19.220
so they revoked a certificate to
invalidate the application that would run

40
00:02:19.220 --> 00:02:22.350
to allow that virus or
ransomware to install.

41
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:24.490
Well when they revoke a certificate,
that's done on their end,

42
00:02:24.490 --> 00:02:27.680
that's on their servers, you actually
don't have to change your Macs at all.

43
00:02:27.680 --> 00:02:31.510
And so that's a very quick thing that
Apple fixes on their servers and

44
00:02:31.510 --> 00:02:33.050
you don't even have an update.

45
00:02:33.050 --> 00:02:35.950
So there's sometimes where
the critical updates aren't

46
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:38.610
something we have to push out,
it's already done for us.

47
00:02:38.610 --> 00:02:42.770
There's other times though, where there's
malicious applications that are out there

48
00:02:42.770 --> 00:02:47.090
and Apple will push an update out to the
Gatekeeper software inside of your Mac,

49
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:48.730
and if you're not
familiar with Gatekeeper,

50
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:51.690
it's one of those things that runs in
the background that we don't normally see.

51
00:02:51.690 --> 00:02:54.530
So for example,
if I go on the internet and

52
00:02:54.530 --> 00:02:59.430
I download a program, the first time I
run it, my Mac might say, hey, this is

53
00:02:59.430 --> 00:03:02.760
a program that was downloaded from the
internet, are you sure you wanna open it?

54
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:05.840
And I can say open it or
not, that's Gatekeeper.

55
00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:08.940
Gatekeeper doesn't allow
just any old program to run

56
00:03:08.940 --> 00:03:10.320
unless you authorize it first.

57
00:03:10.320 --> 00:03:12.690
That stops viruses running
in the background.

58
00:03:12.690 --> 00:03:15.890
Well occasionally hackers find
a way to get around that.

59
00:03:15.890 --> 00:03:17.740
And so they push out a virus and

60
00:03:17.740 --> 00:03:20.090
it starts running on your
machines without you knowing it.

61
00:03:20.090 --> 00:03:22.850
Apple will push an update out
to GateKeeper to tell it to

62
00:03:22.850 --> 00:03:23.810
watch out for that.

63
00:03:23.810 --> 00:03:27.230
And these are security updates that
Apple rolls out from time to time.

64
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:31.030
Those need to go out as soon as you can,
very, very fast.

65
00:03:31.030 --> 00:03:31.760
Get them on your network,

66
00:03:31.760 --> 00:03:33.940
get them deployed out to
your machines very quickly.

67
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:37.190
And so what a lot of people do is they
just configure their Macs to update

68
00:03:37.190 --> 00:03:38.660
automatically.

69
00:03:38.660 --> 00:03:40.650
Let me show you for example, here.

70
00:03:40.650 --> 00:03:41.850
I've got a client,

71
00:03:41.850 --> 00:03:44.690
actually, I can probably even
show you here on my own laptop.

72
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:49.520
So here's my laptop and
I'm running El Capitan and

73
00:03:49.520 --> 00:03:56.000
if I go into my system preferences and
I go into my app store, right

74
00:03:56.000 --> 00:03:59.850
here in the App store you'll see where it
set to automatically check for updates.

75
00:03:59.850 --> 00:04:03.440
And it's gonna download newly
available updates in the background,

76
00:04:03.440 --> 00:04:08.600
it's gonna install them and it's doing
app updates as well as OS X update.

77
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:12.840
So I'm getting my operating system
updates and the apps from the app store.

78
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:15.930
Not apps that are outside the apps store,
if I downloaded the app myself,

79
00:04:15.930 --> 00:04:19.490
I've gotta update it myself, but
ones from the app store are gonna updated.

80
00:04:19.490 --> 00:04:22.790
And then install system data files and
security updates.

81
00:04:22.790 --> 00:04:26.460
So it's set to check for
those and get them.

82
00:04:26.460 --> 00:04:29.410
And then it says automatically download
apps that I purchased or whatever, right.

83
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:31.930
So all of these things are set here to
be able to go and get those updates.

84
00:04:31.930 --> 00:04:36.170
Now Here's the thing,
how often is it checking?

85
00:04:36.170 --> 00:04:38.780
Well, there's actually some
little variations out there, but

86
00:04:38.780 --> 00:04:43.350
most Macs are checking every four to seven
days, so it's not checking terrible often.

87
00:04:43.350 --> 00:04:45.540
It's not checking every
single day by default.

88
00:04:45.540 --> 00:04:48.960
And security updates can come out very
quickly and we need to get them out there.

89
00:04:48.960 --> 00:04:51.660
So, just because a client
is set to be checking for

90
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:54.490
updates, doesn't mean
it's doing it rapidly.

91
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:58.760
And, if you've got 1,000 Macs, how do
you know that these settings are proper?

92
00:04:58.760 --> 00:05:02.090
Well, you can use things like Profile
Manager, and you could push these update

93
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:06.320
settings out or you could bake it into
your net insult images that you push out.

94
00:05:06.320 --> 00:05:10.830
You could use Apple Remote Desktop
to push out the configurations, but

95
00:05:10.830 --> 00:05:12.250
there's an easier way.

96
00:05:12.250 --> 00:05:16.960
And the easier way is to set up your own
software update server and control it.

97
00:05:16.960 --> 00:05:18.700
The other thing is I just
check those boxes there.

98
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:20.260
I said, do the updates.

99
00:05:20.260 --> 00:05:23.970
But that's gonna do the updates and
I don't get to pick and choose.

100
00:05:23.970 --> 00:05:26.990
I can turn that off and make it a manual
process but now if I forget to do it,

101
00:05:26.990 --> 00:05:28.310
I don't get updated.

102
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:31.260
But there's times where updates
come out that I don't wanna do.

103
00:05:31.260 --> 00:05:33.700
I know what you're thinking,
when would I not want an update?

104
00:05:33.700 --> 00:05:34.950
Well, for example,

105
00:05:34.950 --> 00:05:39.480
when El Capitan first came out, it wasn't
exactly a smooth ride for a lot of users.

106
00:05:39.480 --> 00:05:42.380
There was a lot of software that didn't
play nice with El Capitan when it

107
00:05:42.380 --> 00:05:43.330
first came out.

108
00:05:43.330 --> 00:05:45.530
So you might be running Yosemite,
and you say,

109
00:05:45.530 --> 00:05:48.580
hey I don't wanna do that upgrade yet,
I wanna wait.

110
00:05:48.580 --> 00:05:51.710
Well, Apple doesn't like that and they're
gonna keep bugging you to update and

111
00:05:51.710 --> 00:05:53.600
update and update,
you keep getting that message.

112
00:05:53.600 --> 00:05:56.200
Well if I've got 1,000 Macs
that are deployed out there,

113
00:05:56.200 --> 00:05:58.270
I might not be ready for El Capitan yet.

114
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:03.120
And so if I have my own software update
server, I can take that update and

115
00:06:03.120 --> 00:06:04.530
not approve it.

116
00:06:04.530 --> 00:06:07.390
I can approve all the other updates and
leave that one out.

117
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:11.060
So you can start to pick and choose, and
that's what a software update server does.

118
00:06:11.060 --> 00:06:14.830
We will have to have it, your clients can
automatically check on their own, but

119
00:06:14.830 --> 00:06:17.240
having a software update
server gives us that control.

120
00:06:17.240 --> 00:06:19.670
So there's our first best
practice in a corporate or

121
00:06:19.670 --> 00:06:23.360
enterprise environment with a large amount
of machines, take control of the updates.

122
00:06:24.890 --> 00:06:31.040
The second best practice is to set up a
deployment process, a deployment schedule.

123
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:34.670
When an update comes out,
if it's a critical security update,

124
00:06:34.670 --> 00:06:37.000
we want it to go out as fast as possible.

125
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:40.453
But when it's a big update
like a new operating system or

126
00:06:40.453 --> 00:06:45.096
even the smaller updates,
El Capitan I think I'm on 10.11.3 now.

127
00:06:45.096 --> 00:06:49.495
And 10.11.4 is in beta,
I think they're on like 5th beta,

128
00:06:49.495 --> 00:06:54.985
some ridiculous amount of betas for it,
but 10.11.4 is gonna come out soon.

129
00:06:54.985 --> 00:06:57.423
By the time you watch this video
it will probably already be out.

130
00:06:57.423 --> 00:07:00.195
When it comes out,
it's gonna fix some bugs, and

131
00:07:00.195 --> 00:07:02.870
it's going to add some new features.

132
00:07:02.870 --> 00:07:06.370
And those new features,
they could break software that I've got.

133
00:07:06.370 --> 00:07:07.410
I've need to do some testing,

134
00:07:07.410 --> 00:07:11.150
I might not wanna roll that out to
my entire environment on day one.

135
00:07:11.150 --> 00:07:14.500
So apple recommends
a three phase deployment.

136
00:07:14.500 --> 00:07:17.120
Phase one, they call their cooldown.

137
00:07:17.120 --> 00:07:18.300
If an update comes out and

138
00:07:18.300 --> 00:07:23.490
it's not a critical security update,
they recommend waiting seven days.

139
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:25.360
Don't roll it out today.

140
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:26.500
We're gonna wait seven days,

141
00:07:26.500 --> 00:07:29.260
we're gonna wait one week before
we start to look at that update.

142
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:30.930
Now, why wait one week?

143
00:07:30.930 --> 00:07:33.080
Well, if it's an application update or

144
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:36.365
even if it's an Apple update,
sometimes there's bugs.

145
00:07:36.365 --> 00:07:39.740
This new update rolls out and
breaks something.

146
00:07:39.740 --> 00:07:43.910
And if you updated to it right away,
now you gotta try to roll back the update.

147
00:07:43.910 --> 00:07:48.170
And in Mac OS it's easy to do it,
iOS they don't allow you to roll back,

148
00:07:48.170 --> 00:07:50.095
it's really hard to roll back.

149
00:07:50.095 --> 00:07:53.793
So, we wanna make sure that we're ready,
so they recommended waiting a week,

150
00:07:53.793 --> 00:07:56.731
not for a critical security but
if any other update wait a week.

151
00:07:56.731 --> 00:08:01.512
After a week If the vendor hasn't had to
issue any new updates to fix their update,

152
00:08:01.512 --> 00:08:06.450
then it's probably safe but even then, we
don't wanna roll up the update just yet.

153
00:08:07.660 --> 00:08:11.280
Phase two is a test phase.

154
00:08:11.280 --> 00:08:15.140
What we do is we have a small
selection of computers.

155
00:08:15.140 --> 00:08:17.250
I'm might have 1,000
Macs on my network but

156
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:20.090

I'm not sure what folder they would ended

609
00:30:33.750 --> 00:30:37.880
up in, but
there's usually a place holder item.

610
00:30:37.880 --> 00:30:40.020
And then when you download it
the actual update comes in here.

611
00:30:40.020 --> 00:30:44.083
So see these little smd files, these
are just notes that the update exists, and

612
00:30:44.083 --> 00:30:48.042
then when we download it the actual update
will be present in this folder too.

613
00:30:48.042 --> 00:30:49.830
So we get the download placed in here.

614
00:30:49.830 --> 00:30:54.389
So all that's kind of happening in the
background and as those get downloaded and

615
00:30:54.389 --> 00:30:57.751
updated, we can then come back in and
make them available.

616
00:30:57.751 --> 00:31:00.001
So why is this taking so long?

617
00:31:00.001 --> 00:31:01.639
Sometimes it's not that
it takes a long time,

618
00:31:01.639 --> 00:31:03.650
it's just that the screen doesn't refresh.

619
00:31:03.650 --> 00:31:05.000
I just forced to refresh on mine and

620
00:31:05.000 --> 00:31:07.760
I can see this one Downloading,
the other one is still Waiting.

621
00:31:07.760 --> 00:31:10.959
So let's go ahead and
download them to get them in placed.

622
00:31:10.959 --> 00:31:14.880
So once that’s all in place,
I’m now good to go.

623
00:31:14.880 --> 00:31:17.146
I can go here and download updates,
I can enable them,

624
00:31:17.146 --> 00:31:20.115
I can disable them if I don’t want
anybody else to get the updates.

625
00:31:20.115 --> 00:31:22.538
I need to change my mind on that one,
let me disable it, and

626
00:31:22.538 --> 00:31:24.376
now it will stop rolling
out on the network.

627
00:31:24.376 --> 00:31:25.120
>> All right, good Don.

628
00:31:25.120 --> 00:31:26.180
I’m gonna throw you curve ball.

629
00:31:26.180 --> 00:31:27.360
I got a scenario for you.

630
00:31:27.360 --> 00:31:31.280
Hundred of those thousand computers
that just we just set up for

631
00:31:31.280 --> 00:31:34.800
the software update to apply.

632
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:37.980
Let's say, 100 of those computers, I'm
deciding we're gonna give them to charity.

633
00:31:37.980 --> 00:31:40.639
We're gonna to give them to the school and
we no longer want

634
00:31:40.639 --> 00:31:43.751
them pointed to our server,
because they're not on our networks.

635
00:31:43.751 --> 00:31:46.373
Is this a one way street once we set
them up for the software update and

636
00:31:46.373 --> 00:31:47.850
we point them to our internal server?

637
00:31:47.850 --> 00:31:50.491
Can we configure a Mac the other way?

638
00:31:50.491 --> 00:31:52.676
>> Yeah,
you can just delete that preference and

639
00:31:52.676 --> 00:31:54.984
then the system will recreate it and
put it back.

640
00:31:54.984 --> 00:31:58.461
But the best thing, if you're gonna be
sending a computer at to somebody else.

641
00:31:58.461 --> 00:32:02.048
It's best to format it and
put a clean OS back on it and that way,

642
00:32:02.048 --> 00:32:03.760
all those settings are gone.

643
00:32:03.760 --> 00:32:05.310
That'll give you a better reinstall.

644
00:32:05.310 --> 00:32:06.650
But if it's just in a pinch.

645
00:32:06.650 --> 00:32:11.330
If, for example, maybe somebody's
gonna start working from home.

646
00:32:11.330 --> 00:32:12.592
And s,o they're gonna
take their computer home.

647
00:32:12.592 --> 00:32:14.500
And you don't wanna it to have to
reach back into your corporate

648
00:32:14.500 --> 00:32:15.259
network to get updates.

649
00:32:15.259 --> 00:32:16.810
You want them to just go to Apple.

650
00:32:16.810 --> 00:32:20.410
Just delete that preference, and
I use that defaults write command.

651
00:32:20.410 --> 00:32:22.530
You can use the defaults delete and
change it.

652
00:32:22.530 --> 00:32:24.260
Or you can get the actual Apple URI.

653
00:32:24.260 --> 00:32:25.780
I don't know Apple's URL offhand.

654
00:32:27.020 --> 00:32:30.380
But, yeah, I don't know that one offhand.

655
00:32:30.380 --> 00:32:32.050
But if you delete the preference,
it'll recreate it.

656
00:32:32.050 --> 00:32:33.390
It'll just go right back to Apple.

657
00:32:33.390 --> 00:32:35.090
So, there's always that option.

658
00:32:35.090 --> 00:32:37.150
And even if we left it at our server,

659
00:32:37.150 --> 00:32:40.590
if it fails to connect after
enough times it'll bug the user.

660
00:32:40.590 --> 00:32:42.370
And then,
then they'll get a little help document.

661
00:32:42.370 --> 00:32:44.100
It'll show them how to reset that, too.

662
00:32:44.100 --> 00:32:45.370
So, there's a few
different ways it can go.

663
00:32:46.690 --> 00:32:49.291
All right.
But at this point, we're in business.

664
00:32:49.291 --> 00:32:52.680
There's positives to the system and
there's negatives.

665
00:32:52.680 --> 00:32:54.872
On the positive side,
it's pretty easy to implement, wasn't it?

666
00:32:54.872 --> 00:32:58.450
I mean, I really just flipped a switch and
moved some storage, and that was about it.

667
00:32:58.450 --> 00:33:00.040
On negative side,

668
00:33:00.040 --> 00:33:04.200
there's two things that it doesn't
do that people usually ask about.

669
00:33:04.200 --> 00:33:08.925
One thing is, I can't see who all
got the update and who all didn't.

670
00:33:08.925 --> 00:33:09.960
All right?

671
00:33:09.960 --> 00:33:12.380
I just approved a critical
security update.

672
00:33:12.380 --> 00:33:14.240
How do I know everybody got it?

673
00:33:14.240 --> 00:33:15.090
I don't, right?

674
00:33:15.090 --> 00:33:18.560
The Software Update service can't do that,
but Apple Remote Desktop can.

675
00:33:18.560 --> 00:33:22.980
I can go into Apple Remote Desktop and
I can pull the software versions from my

676
00:33:22.980 --> 00:33:25.100
clients and see the updates
that are installed and get it.

677
00:33:25.100 --> 00:33:28.170
So, by itself Software Update
can't show that.

678
00:33:28.170 --> 00:33:29.370
But Apple Remote Desktop can.

679
00:33:29.370 --> 00:33:31.950
So, use the two together to
get that perfect environment.

680
00:33:31.950 --> 00:33:34.218
And the second thing is,
I approved this update.

681
00:33:34.218 --> 00:33:35.200
So, it's rolling out.

682
00:33:35.200 --> 00:33:38.100
Clients are gonna start getting it now,
right?

683
00:33:38.100 --> 00:33:40.810
And let's say that I find
some kind of problem.

684
00:33:40.810 --> 00:33:42.420
It breaks an application.

685
00:33:42.420 --> 00:33:47.810
Well, I can come in here and disable
the update so nobody else is gonna get it.

686
00:33:47.810 --> 00:33:50.650
But what about the people
who already got it?

687
00:33:50.650 --> 00:33:52.640
I don't have a way to revoke the update.

688
00:33:52.640 --> 00:33:55.340
I can't take the update
back once it's out.

689
00:33:55.340 --> 00:33:59.420
And that's why Apple recommends
the phased approach to deploying.

690
00:33:59.420 --> 00:34:03.410
So, remember for the exam, the best
practice, the phase one is seven days.

691
00:34:03.410 --> 00:34:07.240
Wait seven days for rolling out an update
in case the vendor updates it again.

692
00:34:07.240 --> 00:34:10.130
Phase two, spend five days testing.

693
00:34:10.130 --> 00:34:12.510
Just a couple of test machines
to make sure it's okay.

694
00:34:12.510 --> 00:34:16.950
But make sure those machines are typical
use machines, not just IT people.

695
00:34:17.960 --> 00:34:19.580
And then phase three,
general deployment, right?

696
00:34:19.580 --> 00:34:20.660
Roll it out to everybody else.

697
00:34:20.660 --> 00:34:22.130
So, follow that phased approach, and

698
00:34:22.130 --> 00:34:25.680
then you won't need to worry about
revoking that update, and you'll be fine.

699
00:34:25.680 --> 00:34:27.230
>> All right.
Thanks for that information, Don.

700
00:34:27.230 --> 00:34:29.100
Got anything else for us on this one?

701
00:34:29.100 --> 00:34:30.400
>> Just one quick word of caution,

702
00:34:30.400 --> 00:34:32.658
we're gonna do another episode
on the cacheing service.

703
00:34:32.658 --> 00:34:35.890
And the cacheing service overlaps a little
bit with the software update service.

704
00:34:35.890 --> 00:34:37.940
In fact, the two are not compatible.

705
00:34:37.940 --> 00:34:40.760
You gotta pick one or
the other, you can't have both.

706
00:34:40.760 --> 00:34:43.440
So, I really encourage you
to watch our cacheing,

707
00:34:43.440 --> 00:34:44.700
you just watched software update.

708
00:34:44.700 --> 00:34:47.840
But watch our cacheing episode cuz that'll
give you the information you need to

709
00:34:47.840 --> 00:34:50.170
pick which one is gonna benefit you.

710
00:34:50.170 --> 00:34:51.470
You absolutely can't have both.

711
00:34:51.470 --> 00:34:53.010
They don't work together.

712
00:34:53.010 --> 00:34:54.121
There's pros and cons to each.

713
00:34:54.121 --> 00:34:55.750
I'll explain it all in
the cacheing episodes.

714
00:34:55.750 --> 00:34:56.900
So, definitely check that one out.

715
00:34:56.900 --> 00:34:58.250
>> Looking forward to seeing that episode.

716
00:34:58.250 --> 00:35:00.940
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign out for ITProTV.

717
00:35:00.940 --> 00:35:02.720
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

718
00:35:02.720 --> 00:35:03.470
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

719
00:35:03.470 --> 00:35:07.015
>> And we'll see you next time.

720
00:35:07.015 --> 00:35:12.850
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore Caching Software Downloads. They will demonstrate how bring a Caching server online and discuss the types of content that can be cached like Apple Software Updates, iOS App Store Software, Mac App Store Software and iBooks Software. They will talk about how to verify the Caching server is setup and ready through inspecting the logs files and Data store for the Caching server.
episodes.title: Caching Downloads
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.043 --> 00:00:10.043
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.266 --> 00:00:16.317
Welcome to another exciting episode here
at IT Pro TV, I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

3
00:00:16.317 --> 00:00:20.450
in today's episode, we're gonna be
moving along our Mac Management Basics.

4
00:00:20.450 --> 00:00:22.950
We've got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet to help us out with that.

5
00:00:22.950 --> 00:00:24.500
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

6
00:00:24.500 --> 00:00:25.270
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

7
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:27.630
ready to jump right back into
the world of Mac Management Basics.

8
00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:31.710
In this episode, we're gonna be kind of
moving along from our conversation we

9
00:00:31.710 --> 00:00:32.460
had in our last episode.

10
00:00:32.460 --> 00:00:35.940
If you didn't watch our last episode,
it was on the software update service.

11
00:00:35.940 --> 00:00:37.910
Now we can push out
updates to our systems.

12
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:40.990
Today, we're gonna take a look
at the caching service, and

13
00:00:40.990 --> 00:00:44.260
the caching service is very similar
to software updates we'll see,

14
00:00:44.260 --> 00:00:46.500
there's a little bit of
overlap between the two.

15
00:00:46.500 --> 00:00:49.210
The comment I made at the end
of the last episode was

16
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:52.740
when you go to deploy this stuff in
the real world, you have to pick

17
00:00:52.740 --> 00:00:55.920
between the software update service we
talked about in the last episode and

18
00:00:55.920 --> 00:00:58.750
the caching service we're gonna
talk about in this episode.

19
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:02.750
Each one has their pros and cons,
their benefits and drawbacks, so you've

20
00:01:02.750 --> 00:01:05.290
gotta figure out which one is the most
realistic for you and in your environment.

21
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:07.980
So that's what we're gonna be taking
a look at right here in this episode.

22
00:01:07.980 --> 00:01:12.620
>> Don, when it comes to caching,
in caching platforms in general,

23
00:01:12.620 --> 00:01:15.040
it's about a common set of data
that we need access to, and

24
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:17.200
it can kinda speed up performance and
stuff.

25
00:01:17.200 --> 00:01:19.080
Is that where we're heading
with caching server?

26
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:21.000
>> Yeah, absolutely.

27
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:23.890
Let's think in terms of updates,
I don't wanna pigeonhole us to updates but

28
00:01:23.890 --> 00:01:24.570
we'll start it there.

29
00:01:25.700 --> 00:01:30.560
Let's say that Apple
releases a big OS update,

30
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:34.600
right now, I'm running Mac OS 10.11.3, so

31
00:01:34.600 --> 00:01:39.611
El Capitan's had three minor revisions and
I'm on 10.11.3.

32
00:01:39.611 --> 00:01:45.080
Let's say tomorrow 10.11.4 comes out and
the update is 600 megabytes in size.

33
00:01:45.080 --> 00:01:47.240
They're usually like 600 to a gig in size,

34
00:01:47.240 --> 00:01:51.580
somewhere around there but that update
comes out and that's the size of it.

35
00:01:51.580 --> 00:01:54.520
My Mac is gonna reach out to Apple and
check in and say, look,

36
00:01:54.520 --> 00:01:58.060
there's an update available and it's gonna
download it and it's gonna install it.

37
00:01:58.060 --> 00:02:00.710
That's fine, that system works great,
we don't need to mess with it.

38
00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:04.377
But what if I had 1,000 Macs?

39
00:02:04.377 --> 00:02:06.610
If I have 1,000 Macs,

40
00:02:06.610 --> 00:02:12.350
they all reach out to Apple, they all see
that update and they all download it.

41
00:02:12.350 --> 00:02:17.410
When they downloaded 1,000 machines
downloading 600 megs of data,

42
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:20.740
you end up with over terabyte of
data that's being transferred,

43
00:02:20.740 --> 00:02:24.260
actually several terabytes of data that's
being pulled down and that's a lot.

44
00:02:24.260 --> 00:02:27.290
Depending on your wide area network,
depending on your internet connectivity

45
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:30.220
and other things, it can really affect
the performance of your network.

46
00:02:30.220 --> 00:02:31.640
We don't necessarily want that,

47
00:02:31.640 --> 00:02:34.230
especially since all the machines
are getting the same data.

48
00:02:34.230 --> 00:02:39.430
What you said, Wes, is that common set of
data, it's one update that's identical for

49
00:02:39.430 --> 00:02:41.740
everybody but
everybody's downloading it independently.

50
00:02:43.020 --> 00:02:45.920
In the last episode, we saw where we
could use a software update server

51
00:02:45.920 --> 00:02:50.040
where you can download that update and
have it on your own update server.

52
00:02:50.040 --> 00:02:51.730
And then your 1,000 Macs,

53
00:02:51.730 --> 00:02:55.340
instead of them all going out to
the internet to get the update,

54
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:58.390
they just reach out to the software
update server and they get it from there.

55
00:02:59.420 --> 00:03:02.190
Now you have 1,000 Macs that
all update locally, and

56
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:04.760
only the update server goes out to Apple.

57
00:03:04.760 --> 00:03:08.540
Now that works really well, and it has
the added benefit of letting us pick and

58
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:11.310
choose which updates apply and
which updates don't, so

59
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:12.980
we get some benefits there.

60
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:16.190
But It only works for updates.

61
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:18.770
What about other stuff?

62
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:22.120
What about apps that I
install from the App Store?

63
00:03:22.120 --> 00:03:24.600
What about books that we
purchase through iBooks?

64
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:33.790
What about iOS, the software update
server that we saw, that was just for

65
00:03:33.790 --> 00:03:36.480
Mac OS updates, for OS 10.

66
00:03:36.480 --> 00:03:39.520
But what if I have iPads and
iPhones and they've got apps and

67
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:44.480
their operating systems, the IOS platform,
all of those get updated too.

68
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:47.040
Software update server
doesn't take care of that.

69
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:51.030
It doesn't provide any caching or
data reduction for

70
00:03:51.030 --> 00:03:54.890
those technologies but
caching service does.

71
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:57.826
The caching service can be turned on,
on any Mac OS server.

72
00:03:57.826 --> 00:04:00.200
Any OS 10,
where we've installed the server app,

73
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:05.880
we can turn on caching and that caching
server will just watch the network.

74
00:04:05.880 --> 00:04:08.450
And the first time somebody
downloads something,

75
00:04:08.450 --> 00:04:10.660
the caching server will get a copy of it.

76
00:04:10.660 --> 00:04:14.190
And then anytime anyone else
tries to get that file,

77
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:16.030
the caching server's already got it and

78
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:19.550
it saves us from having to download
those files over and and over again.

79
00:04:19.550 --> 00:04:22.000
And it goes beyond software updates.

80
00:04:22.000 --> 00:04:25.230
It does do software updates,
the caching server does do that but

81
00:04:25.230 --> 00:04:29.660
it also does apps that were purchased
through the App Store, either iOS or

82
00:04:29.660 --> 00:04:31.380
Mac OS, either of the App Stores.

83
00:04:31.380 --> 00:04:34.700
It does, I already said software updates,
I'm getting redundant now.

84
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:40.070
It does iBooks purchases, it does
the crazy corporate account type of stuff.

85
00:04:40.070 --> 00:04:42.370
If you've got one of those special
accounts set up with Apple,

86
00:04:42.370 --> 00:04:43.210
if you're school, for

87
00:04:43.210 --> 00:04:47.090
example, you might buy textbooks where
it rolls out to all the devices.

88
00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:49.024
You gonna cache those too, so
it caches a lot of things.

89
00:04:49.024 --> 00:04:50.576
I feel like I'm leaving something out.

90
00:04:50.576 --> 00:04:51.940
What am I leaving out?

91
00:04:51.940 --> 00:04:54.040
No, that's pretty much it.

92
00:04:54.040 --> 00:04:58.650
[LAUGH] It caches all that stuff,
and then any time somebody goes

93
00:04:58.650 --> 00:05:02.860
to download it again, it's got it
right there on the caching server.

94
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:04.560
It could be a software
update that's critical,

95
00:05:04.560 --> 00:05:08.340
that's really important, or it could
be Angry Birds from the iOS App Store.

96
00:05:08.340 --> 00:05:10.780
Doesn't matter,
they get cached on the caching server.

97
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:13.460
The second time somebody
goes to download it,

98
00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:14.529
it pulls right from the caching server.

99
00:05:15.850 --> 00:05:17.870
Now, how does this work?

100
00:05:17.870 --> 00:05:19.630
It actually works on a pretty neat system.

101
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:23.210
I told Wes before the show, that usually
we have these labs in the show, and

102
00:05:23.210 --> 00:05:24.550
I've got all these steps written out.

103
00:05:24.550 --> 00:05:26.612
You guys have probably seen
the papers on the desk.

104
00:05:26.612 --> 00:05:29.340
Normally, they're just littered
with step after step after step for

105
00:05:29.340 --> 00:05:30.960
what we're going to do in the labs.

106
00:05:30.960 --> 00:05:34.000
The caching server is so
insanely easy to turn on though,

107
00:05:34.000 --> 00:05:36.620
that I don't even have lab
steps written down cuz

108
00:05:36.620 --> 00:05:38.870
you really just flip an on switch and
the caching service is on.

109
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:42.970
It's designed to be as
automatic as possible,

110
00:05:43.980 --> 00:05:47.080
which begs the question of if it's
completely automatic, how does it work?

111
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:50.740
When we did software updates, we had
to turn on the software update server.

112
00:05:50.740 --> 00:05:52.380
We had to tell it to download the updates.

113
00:05:52.380 --> 00:05:55.615
We had to approve the updates for
distribution.

114
00:05:55.615 --> 00:05:58.580
Then we had to go to our clients, we had
to point the clients to the update server.

115
